Being saddled with these 2 lumps of blah would be bad enough,but the story is a forced march through cliches and twists so predictable they have no real turns at all. You'll pretty much guess the plot within seconds of the motivations of a character being questioned. And the whole thing could have been avoided had anyone in the cast shown an ounce of common sense. Not just the main characters,any one.  The jokes are so bad,so devoid of any real humor. I didn't even register them AS jokes half the time until a character laughed. The whole thing is just boring and dull and most of my time sitting there playing was wishing the whole thing was over with and that there'd be some kind of pay off.  And at the end of it all,there isn't. The heroes are the heroes and the villians are the villains and at the end of it all,everyone is friends. Good god. Just 'hey,all's forgiven even though you tried to kill us several times.' And this ♥♥♥♥ was from the same people who gave us Psychonauts! And Brutal Legend! Games with fun stories and relatable characters and funny dialogue. I just don't even wanna think about what this means for Double Fine.  I'm just done. ♥♥♥♥ Tim,♥♥♥♥ Double Fine,♥♥♥♥ this game.
Absolutely loved this game! This is the best character development and plot I've seen in a long, long time.

In soul, I think this is a fantastic game. But it's not for me. Nevertheless, I think it's a good gateway to 'point and click' adventure games. Act 1 is like, the casual version of it. And the act 2 is for the veteran version of it. And the world & characters & artstyle are so strong, that the game feels truly alive in the moments of 'not -back & forth- walking'. Even though I had to check internet aid in pretty early in act 2, I also got puzzles that made me use pen & paper, which is fantastic.
Basically, 3 hours of play time for $20. Not cool

Sweet jeesus, what the hell guys? This game is not worth the praise it's gotten just because it's, at best, ok. I don't really care for point and click games that much, but even I've played way better - what the hell have you guys been playing?  YEAHYEAH the music is good, the art is neat in it's own way blahblahblah. The voice acting is decent (save for the ultra-mousey and annoying as hell Vella) but I expect that with the cast that's on it. 3 million dollars you accomplished that much - congratulations.  First off, I wasn't expecting to beat this in about 5 hours, that's bad. I know it's in two acts, but we're sitting at 10 hours play time total? And I was lazy while playing it since I was bored by the 'amazing' story.  Revolutionary? By no means. I mean, how is this at all advancing or re-defining the genre? I get that there's not a lot of point-and-click titles, filled with crap like Anna and Gone Home... but if you think this game changes anything for the better, you just aren't familiar with the genre. At all. Maybe that's why everyone keeps gushing out the word 'nostalgia' - as if boasting about rarely playing a genre makes you a better game reviewer.   Honestly, you can get the Deponia series for cheap thru the frequent semi-annual sales on steam, and all three acts are good games on their OWN, you don't even need all three. They are filled with at least 10-12 hours *per chapter* and with more interesting and inventive puzzles and game mechanics. You know what else you get as opposed to this game? An interesting story, amusing dialogue, and much better characters. I cannot see anyone playing the Deponia series and coming out praising Broken Age. This is just very boring pretty fluff.

For even with the lowered price HOLIDAY SALE's 13,79e, the game isn't worth it. I would gladly pay 5-10 euros but considering the playing hours, you can get so much more with current price tag.   The graphics and the sounds are amazing. I was amazed all the time how well everything was made, until I realised that the game was allready over. The 'puzzles' weren't puzzles. When making a point and click, you should be looking at games from 90's. This was, (like the all unpopular games these days) too easy.

Everything about this game is awesome, and it was well worth the wait.   - Music is great - Puzzles are fairly challenging at times - Voice acting is very enjoyable and funny :D - Loved the art work and style of the game - There are lots of things to see through multiple play-throughs such as different dialogue you may have missed  If you like these time of games then I think you'll love it, if not don't get it. If you are upset it too so long to come out just know it was time well spent instead of being rushed. This is a lovely game and I recommend it highly :D hope this was helpful to you. I can't wait to play through it again and get all the achievements this time!

How could you go wrong with a game comming from Double Fine studio? It's amazing in every aspect! Where should i start? The virusals.. the musical score.. the voice acting.. Just the very first scene of Vella waking up under a tree sets the tone for the rest of the adventure. It's enchanting. It's like watching your very first cartoons with children's eyes. There are quite enough puzzle, mostly very easy, but the adventure focusses more on the dialogues which you souldn't miss a single line as they are so well written and acted. Elijah Wood, Jack Black, Will Wheaton, ... even Pendleton Ward is in it :) For the french speaking person i am not very much used to recognize english actors by their voice, i was surprised and pleased to recognize them in the game! The subtitles are very well translated, by the way. Really, it praises quality ... over quantity, which is the game's only downside. The game is very short (typical for point'n'click adventure games) and Act2 isn't even released yet, but it will be soon and for free. I just can't wait for it. Thanks Tim Schafer and Double Fine production. I knew from the start my money was on the right horse.

This game is very good, but not as good as Grim Fandango.  Broken Age is a point and click adventure game by Tim Schafer, about two teenagers who live two seemingly different lives. First there is a girl who has been chosen to be sacrificed to a monster but decides to fight back. Second, is a boy who has been raised on a spaceship by an overprotective super computer, but now he wants more excitement in his life.  The art style and environments are gorgeous and Imaginative, the characters you interact with are colorful and memorable, and the humor is well written. The story, while not as good as some of Tim’s past work, is a pretty decent story with some interesting twists and turns along the way. And while I do believe the game’s ending does leave some questions unanswered, I personally found it satisfying.  My personal problem with the game was that some of the puzzles felt a bit too cryptic. I felt like I was forced to find the solutions online, and after finding the solutions, it made me wonder how any normal person would figure them out without having to resort to a walkthrough. It would have been helpful if the game had a hint button like they had in the Monkey Island special edition. Despite this, it didn’t really ruin the experience for me.  If you in the mood for a nice, charming, adventure game then I would recommend checking it out. It may not be perfect, but is still an experience worth having. I give this game a 7.7/10.

Great story that is compelling with hilarious moments. Good challenge for the most part with a few puzzles/actions that I have no idea how someone is supposed to randomly figure out what to do next. Wish there was more!

It's pretty if you like the art style, not a massive fan of it myself but you can see how people would find it beautiful. Everything is a bit sparse, very few things to interact with.  Puzzles are absurdly simple, there's a couple of odd leaps of logic as per standard but since you have such a tiny inventory and so few things to interact with it's hard to get stuck. Given this was backed on the love of oldschool adventure gamers, this should've been way more of a focus. Also for people who are used to exploring rooms you'll find a lot of dialog is out of place - your character is suddenly asking around about things they've not yet heard of.  The two stories are charming but shallow, old adventure games were marketed at kids but the complexity of them was what made them stick. This has none.  It's hard to picture how DoTT had a budget of 600k, while they only managed half a game with a tiny fraction of the depth, with 3.3million  In Act 2: Puzzles go from barely existing to frustratingly vague, random and even glitched to impossibility. They don't even make sense, the two characters need to share knowledge on several occasions through the player, there is no possible way each could get the solutions the other needs to find out for them. For one of them there is NO way to find out the answer, you have to just rely on the fact it's not the other 3 options and the game has given you a fourth out of the blue.   A lot of the fail states are mind numbingly boring to reset - do it enough times and the game will actually step in and cut out some of the steps so it's not like they weren't aware the puzzles kinda sucked.  I'm sort of imagining this is the backlash from everyone complaining act 1 was too easy, but there's a thing called balance and this is both of the worst ends of the spectrum.  Story wraps up in record time - but still makes no sense - and then the finale is forced and anticlimactic, dialogue is much shorter, much less witty, character development is nil. Revelations that should be earth-shattering and psyche-breaking are shrugged off in seconds. The ending not only doesn't make sense, it doesn't even solve anything.  All in all if this were a quirky bargain bin game then sure pick it up, play for a bit and then forget. As a story it's a mess that clearly wasn't planned in advance. As a promised hark back to the old school games of yore, it's a nail in their coffin.   This is not the game we backed.

Ugly, cheap, boring point and click wayyyyy too expensive for what it's worth and how much time and money it took to make. Please don't give money to doublefine, so we don't have to suffer another thing like this one.
Great for kids and adults alike. Enjoyed it thoroughly and many funny moments for all. If you don't like this your creative side needs an ♥♥♥♥♥.

Act 1 was good, nice graphics, voice acting and intriguing story. When may cat eats a lot of  green  grass, he pukes hairballs. This is Act 2.  I backed this game and few others on kickstarter. Never again.

I would be hard pressed to call Broken Age a game; it's more an interactive story. Coming from DoubleFine though, you get what you'd expect: goofy and endearing characters that hint at a deeper, darker lore that permeates the environment. While I enjoyed Vella's side more than Shay's, each character stood comfortable (and confidently) on their own - heading towards an inevitable conjunction.

Wow, I just finished Act 1 in Broken Age, and it was awesome! Fascinating story, insane twists, some good humour, interesting puzzles, this is a great point-and-click game! I don't often go for point-and-click, I'm more of a survival horror or realistic FPS gamer, however I'm very glad that I bought this. The artwork, the soundtrack, the voice acting (I swear one of the characters sound like Jack Black!), and the world that is portrayed is very unique. I sadly only got 4 hours out of the playthrough (Yeah, Angry Joe wouldn't approve...), but it was 4 hours of quality. If Act 2 is included in this purchase, I'd definitely say it's worth the price, however if Act 2 is a whole seperate game that costs more than $15, I might think twice.   Yeah it's awesome, but I don't think there's much replay value here. I guess it all depends, if you like interesting characters, stories, worlds, twists, all in an artistic point-and-click game that will more than likely have some sequels, yet can overlook a somewhat lack of replayability and a less than 5 hour playthrough, then this is definitely for you. I typically consider myself a strictly FPS/RPG/Survival Horror gamer, yet this caught my attention and I'm glad I played it, so I suggest giving it a look to see if it tickles your fancy. Shooty-bang-s'plody-wow is good fun, but so is sitting down with an easy going story-driven point-and-click as well :)

Bearing in mind we have only half a game its hard to rate it. Ultimately what we have so far is disappointing. Its too short and hasn't really got much interactivity. There isn't any scope to really do anything. I admit one puzzle had me stumped for a bit (the train) because I didn't realise you could undo something.  The graphics are lovely and Peter McConnell's music is a joy to hear. Seriously, the soundtrack is highly recommended.

The short play time is due to the fact I finished the game via the Humble Bundle version also offered to backers.  I wanted to like this game but it's just too short, incomplete and in no way challenging. I'm through giving Double Fine and Tim Schafer money. The critcism of this game can be applied to all their/his recent projects.  I'm starting to think Ron Gilbert carried him and that all the critcism was right.

This is how a point and click adventure should be done. Wonderful story, beautiful art & amazing voice acting. The ability to move between Vella and Shay's stories is great (because if you get stuck you can try the other story for awhile) I can't wait for Act 2 to come out!
The game is really great! Don't listen to all these haters. There aren't many adventure games are coming out nowadays and that's very game is absolutely worth your attention if you like this genre!

I can't say how much I recommend this game. This game is literally the reason I got into gaming (I saw the NPR piece about it and I knew I had to get my hands on something that lovely).   Story: The first half is fantastic story. In the documentary they pointed out that things really kick up once Merrick shows up and that's definitely true. You don't really know what is going on or who to trust. Then you have the end of the first half and the beginning of the second half.   The big mysteries in the first half are pretty quickly filled in within the second half but personally I loved the ways they were revealed (for one my husband was watching over my shoulder and exclaimed in surprise) and that the focus of the game was then executing specific tasks, rather than hunting for clues.   I also really liked the ending; it reminded me strongly of the ending of Transistor with it's understated approach and use of the credits.   Overall the story was just suspenseful/unnerving enough without being something I wouldn't recommend to younger players and fantastically winsome and memorable.   Character Balance/Development: In the first half Vella's world is more flat than Shay's. She's less clearly motivated and the objects she carries don't result in really any clever dialogue at all (as far as clicking on them in inventory, offering them to everyone, etc). Shay's world on the other hand was amazingly rich. The spoon and knife I didn't really discover until my second play through and they alone make his entire world more charming.   In the second half that's much more balanced. While Shay still has more interesting tasks since he isn't trapped as much in one locale, Vella picks up the knife and a fork and some new characters show up in her locale (along with an old one I was really hoping we hadn't seen the end of!) that give her more engagement. Shay has more of the 'I don't think we can use that that way' lines in the second half.   Shay is in my opinion more rounded and makes more sense than Vella. We don't get a good sense of Vella without really digging into one or two lines; otherwise she comes off as needlessly and oddly intense. But they are both very winning and you feel a vested interest in them.   One thing character wise that bugged me in the second half was the fact that one character stands around on a beach and you can't really talk to him. His big issue is pretty easily solved and then he's just there for most of the game. If you try to talk to him you get the auto 'Never mind!' line and have to walk away. That seemed really pointless.   Puzzles:  They are definitely uneven but not unduly so. The first half of the game they are realizing things are not as they seem. The second half they are trying to cope with certain big revelations and new realities. It makes sense that other things are suddenly harder as well.   I have NO idea why people hate the second half so much. The puzzles are clever but not so obscure that you would never get them (I found the knot puzzle easy while I would miss certain more obvious items, like how to get the shell). Most of the time if one side got old I would switch and play the other and suddenly things would make sense to me. So I felt like it played very smoothly. You need to diagram some things out but please, that's point and click standard. If you don't see that as the sign of a good game then don't play point and click.   I also didn't understand the claims some have made about not having a hint system. When your character tells you 'Maybe I should look for X' how is that NOT a hint? Same with your character asking another repeatedly if thing X will cause reaction Y.   I like all others would have liked more new territory, but again, that's point and click standard to have one environment you really scrub over again and again. If it had all been released at once it would have been less striking.   I know there's more I could say here but these were the reasons I got into the game and these are the only things that really matter to me. It's a gorgeous game that is incredibly addicting and charming. If this appeals to you at all, buy it! It's well worth every cent!

Delivers on it's promises. A charming point and click adventure game, with well written characters, an intresting story, and clever puzzels. The difficulty between part 1 and 2 is a bit uneven, but otherwise I very much enjoyed playing this.

This review is in regards to Act 1, since Act 2 is not available yet.  Personally, I gladly recommend Broken Age, but I'm going to say right now that it's DEFINITELY not something that will fit everyone's gaming tastes. It's a point-and-click adventure, of course, but a very simple one; sometimes the only difficulty that arose was from temporarily looking over an item that needs to be used. I'm not sure if it's even possible to truly fail this game, to be honest. The game is short, simple enough if you pay attention, and doesn't particularly fall prey to the Sierra Logic issues that sometimes come with point-and-click games (Sierra games were infamous in particular for occasionally having puzzles with solutions that were so absurd, they didn't make sense). If you're looking for a complex puzzle game or something involving some combat, then you should look elsewhere.  I recommend this game mostly on the merit of the story, music, and art style. If you've ever played Double Fine games before (Psychonauts comes to mind), then you'll have an idea of what sort of tone this game's story has. I enjoyed the characters and settings, short as everything was, and I'm glad I played it. I wish there had been more to do at least in some of the interactions, but considering this is part 1 of a 2-part game, I'm not going to hold it against the game.  What this review basically comes down to is if you can like a game mostly for the story and style, then this may be good to look into. If you want a challenging sort of gameplay experience, though? It's probably not worth your time.

This game is unfinished as it is, leaving you with a bit of a cliffhanger, but (I believe), part 2 is included in the price when it is finally released. It has two seemingly very different characters with their own environment, story and puzzles. You can switch between them at any point, though I never really saw a need for this and played each one straight through. Truly imaginative worlds with great art, interesting plot, AWESOME voice acting (Elijah Wood, Wil Wheaton)... I have high hopes for part 2!  Update for Part 2: Once again, you play as two separate characters in different worlds, but what you do in one world actually matters, which was a departure from Part 1. You find out key details you need in one world by interacting with the other. The puzzles were much more complicated an finicky for the second part than the first, causing some annoyance.  Pros: +Voice acting +Awesome art +Interesting worlds +Good puzzles +Good story  Cons: -Second half of the game was MUCH more frustrating puzzle-wise. -First half of the game has little to no crossover between the two characters you play, making the dual storylines seem useless until the second half  Overall: 9/10. A great adventure game.
this is a $300k game that took 3.3 million dollars to make  don't buy this game  stop giving tim schafer money  you have to scold him like a bad dog  you say NO to that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥
I haven't played a P&C game since Broken Sword 2: TSM since i was not very keen on the genre. This game made me rethink about that.

A very socially progressive game, can be interpreted in many ways and also looks very very nice! The puzzles difficulty is kinda like easy-medium, the game really gives you quite some hints (finished it without walkthrough). It's worth your money and your time !

I'm sorry, please forgive me. I'm co-responsible for this dullness: I was among those who kickstarted this (so I got early access and already have it).  We gave Double Fine over 8 times more money than they had asked for. Yet somehow it turned out it still wasn't enough for them: they went over schedule, needed some extra funding, made some cuts and are releasing it in parts. But the worst is...  ...it is just as insignificant, inconsistent and boring as Monkey Island and Grim Fandango were fabulous, great and funny. What happened?  By far it doesn't look like the same Schafer we knew and loved. Pity, pity, pity: mine and everyone else's hopes were so high. We really believed he coud give us another gem, but it seems time has had it's toll and he's spent. So sad.  Please Tim, making things strange and weird does not make them interesting. Oddness that has no motive and ends nowhere can titillate curiosity for a short time, but ends up being only boring and irritating.  We still love you and many of us are longing for great adventure games. We would love to get more of those from you. I'm sure you can still be a great team-leader and motivator, but maybe you should pass the creative leadership to some other artist who still has something innovative and interesting to say. PLEASE! Thank you.

You'll either hate it or love it - as such, it's a game about duality and how seemingly unrelated paths through crazy circumstances lead to one point.  While I was not a backer for the original Kickstarter campaign (I didn't start backing games on that site until last year), I did follow their journey through the DoubleFine Adventure via epsidoes released every so often on YouTube, and let me tell you - it's a whole other experience watching a game being made, and THEN playing it. In short: it was an intimate experience, and I have much better understanding as a gamer about how the other side of the coin operates.  I played Broken Age all the way through in one sitting - due to the anticipation from fans, I felt it was most appropriate to play it that way since serveral people complained about the 'broken' experience where they whizzed through Act 1, then waited, waited, waited, got impatient, then brute-forced Act 2. If your experience was like that, I'm sorry you feel hatred towards this game, but your particular experience casued your particular reaction. The game, while it may feel unevenly paced, is still an enjoyable game in what many modern gamers consider to be 'A dying genre'. Adventure games are here to stay, as long as people play them, classics, remakes, or modern ones, it makes no difference.  The art direction is great, the music is excellent, the animation (while not Disney calibur), fits the artwork appropriately and tolerable. The mechanics are as-expected for a Point-and-Click adventure, along with controller support (if that's your thing). The story is interesting enough to keep you moving ahead, even if some puzzles are frustrating until you look up hints or draw a diagram on a post-it or two (like I did for that Hexpals wiring puzzle) - it only makes you more satisfied once you finish. Depending on your first playthrough, you may or may not want to do it again to snag all of the achievements (for you Perfectionists/Completionists/Achievement Hunters out there).  Overall, if you love the magic of Double Fine games, if you love Adventure games, if you like games that try to do something different and pray somebody will appreciate it, play this game. Whether you come to love it or hate it, at least acknowledge the money, the hard work, and most of all, the love that Tim Schafer and friends put into the game.  It's worth the experience.
Double fine games have about 2 hours of content.
This game is so funny, pretty and nice to play. The difficulty is just perfect, sometimes leaves you breaking your brain for a short while, and the dialogs are really funny. I am enjoying it a lot.

So, there it is.  Broken Age  is finally out. I haven't touched it before tonight (bought it sometime last year during a sale) and waited patiently for it to be ready for a full-on, one-session playthrough. The question is: Was it worth the wait?  The (spoiler-free) answer to that is: Yes it was, if you have been patient and didn't raise your expectations too high.   Now, something to say right away -  Broken Age  is not the adventure to end all adventures. It has its strengths and weaknesses. But what makes assessing them hard is that they switch around. In Act 1, the story was very strong and somewhat mysterious while the puzzles were mostly fairly easy. In Act 2, the story lost a lot of its pull (in my opinion) but the puzzles became more complex and challenging, some of them just the right amount to be satisfying, some pushing it a little (or well) into the realm of the frustrating.  But I will not blame Double Fine for experimenting with some of the concepts behind puzzles. The fewer developers keep recycling the same concept, content and game over and over, the better, so I can admit I was satisfied with that part of the game even though I eventually had to look up a hint or two.  The story left a somewhat bitter aftertaste, though. It's not that it's bad overall - The presentation is brilliant, the setup stellar (particularly Shay's Act 1 was great) and the cast of experienced and skilled (voice) actors add to it, as do the beatiful soundtrack and catching visuals. And the writing also doesn't leave a lot to be desired: It's witty, but not too over-the-top and just the right amount of educational to be played by all ages. It does, however, suffer from what I would call the 'Mass Effect 3' effect: By the end, it seems like nobody really knew what to do with it, so it was just wrapped up in whatever way they could. It's not as bad as Mass Effect 3 but I found the conclusion unsatisfying and the last few scenes made me wonder where the good writing with its surprises and twists had gone and why I was now watching a B movie.  I know that doesn't sound like a hearty recommendation but that doesn't mean you shouldn't pick it up.  Broken Age  is still a great adventure; it just isn't without faults, just like the story of its development.   Be aware, though, that you are probably only going to get one playthrough of 8-10 hours out of it (maybe another some years later). But during a sale, this is a good pick.

This is a great game, engrossing storyline that pulls you in and makes you want to keep going. Only downside is waiting for act 2 to be released but I think it is definitly worth the wait! Money well spent in my opinion.

Broken Age....is amazing, i dont understand why people dont like it. The music is wonderful, the graphics are interesting, the humor is hilarious and every puzzle is quite difficult and logical! (expect for that one part where you HAD TO PUT SHOES ON A LADDER) Sure, sometimes the game is kinda stupid at some parts, but double fine had to sorta rush Act 2 so we could enjoy it and see what happens to Shey and Vella. Broken Age has the same charm that I've come to expect from Schafer's games, like Psychonauts, Costume Quest and Stacking. The characters are interesting though admittedly one-dimensional (just like most point and click adventure games) and the conversations are mostly quite entertaining. I think the voice acting is superb as well, especially with the two main characters and the Computer ('Mom'). The animation and visuals prove that a game does not need super high def SSAO bloom TressFX etc etc to set the atmosphere of a game in the right direction. The overall aesthetic (visuals, music, ambience) elicit zero complaints from me.   Unfortunately, the same cannot be said of the gameplay. I'm not sure what I was expecting, but I found the item hunting a bit tiring at times. I wish there was a way to speed up conversations, as I generally read much faster than people speak (pressing space will skip the entire conversation, not just the current dialogue with subtitles) and though there are some areas where your character can run, most of the time you walk at a very slow clip. I'm glad that there isn't much hand holding, but when certain areas open up, it can be a bit annoying to walk back and forth between screens looking for an item I missed.   Still, it's not like I did not enjoy the gameplay at all. I think the clever dialogue (and even off hand remarks as I look at items or walk past characters) cracked me up, and that makes a ton of difference in adventure games. I had an idea of where the story was heading at first, but now I'm not so sure. All I know is that Act 2 cannot come soon enough.

At this point, I might as well proclaim my undying love to Tim Schafer. It seems every title I've touched with him behind the director's chair reminds me why I love video games.  Apparently 16 years since his last point-and-click adventure game, Grim Fandango, and the man still knows how to work it. I mean it's not like he wasn't doing anything, with Psychonauts and Brutal Legends druid-plowing themselves into my favorite's list, but point-and-clicks are very different from your normal genre. Practically visual novels; if the story or context doesn't hook you, there's nothing to go back for it aside from meager puzzles.  Luckly Broken Age hooks you from the start with both, and beautiful artwork to boot. Shay and Vella's story is nothing new, something we've seen or read plently times before, but Tim Schafer's spin leaves it refreshing. For example, Shay's situation is entirely understandable, where he puts a mental barrier between him and the 'Computer' who is taking care of him. Although never brought up by Shay or the game itself, it's likely only programmed to take care of him - it isn't true love and concern. Yet all it takes is some lovely voice-work provided by the ever awesome Jennifer Hale and a small story toward Shay, and I can't help but feel sad for 'Computer'. Damn you, Shay, just call her 'Mom' for once.  Contrary to what I'm saying above, the game is light-hearted. Vella's story about sacrificing maidens is not as grim as you'd imagine it to be. No blood or gore, just a small glimpse of a body as it's devoured by a giant species of monster called a Mog. Yet that's part of its charm. Combined with its watercolor artwork and peaceful soundtrack, it's as if I'm reading a children's storybook. Then you eventually come across someone whose name is shortened to Ch't.... heh-heh.  All and all, I am very looking forward to Act 2. Having started Shay's story first, I thought I had an idea of where his story ended when I was nearing the end of Vella's. The end of Act 1 practically told me 'Nope,' punched me in the face, and jumped off a cliff. I'd pay again in order for it to come sooner, but like everyone else, I'll have to wait for the free update... whenever that is.  C'mon, Tim. Don't do this to me, man. I needs it. I needs it now~

OK - Just finished the game and here are my thoughts:  What I loved: + Writing, voice acting and some jokes are clever. + Variety of weirdly thought out characters such as a talking spoon. + Plot is clevery written + Graphics are charming and in 2D.  What I didn't like: - There are not much of areas to explore. It felt compact. - While the plot is clevery written, it still does not capture what made classic adventure game stories interesting. There isn't much to get interested in the two main characters (Shay and Vella). We are simply solving their life problems. - Very simplistic point-and-click game. Clicking on an object will automatically trigger whatever the progammer wanted it to be. Sometimes the character would comment on it, sometimes will try to 'activate it' and sometimes will take it. I'd prefer it if it reused the verb technique, like in Curse of Monkey Island (Look at, Use/Pickup, Talk/Eat). - The puzzles at the end of the game were frustrating and confusing.  Verdict: It is a return to classic adventure games alright but I don't see it surpassing my favourite classics (Full Throttle, Monkey Island, Grim Fandango, Sam and Max). However, it is still a recommended game for all those who still want Adventure Games. It is better than whatever Telltale is doing with Game of Thrones, that I can tell ya.

It could have been a lot more but overall it stikes you as a children's adventure game rather than the 'Double-fine adventure!' I was promised. As someone who likes logical consistency there's a lot of the old-style lucas arts, and third party adventure game puzzle farts where there's an incredible logical leap to solve a puzzle even though it doesn't make much sense and it gives off the impression of being simultaneously lazy and genius at the same time. Not recommended. I would give it a 7.5/10 for art style because while it's not well animated the design is intriguing, and 5/10 for the story because there's no consistency, flow, or real story to speak of besides what is presented topically but there are definitely some interesting concepts which are brushed on the surface but never dug into sadly. Hope you enjoy it more than I did.

I've had mixed feelings for this game when the first part came out.   I didn't like the 'coming of age' story concept (not my issues anymore), I didn't like the setting (childish fantasy-world), the dialogue wasn't all that witty/funny, and the puzzles were simplistic. HOWEVER, as the hours trickled by, I slowly came to like that game. It was the little details that reminded me of Tim Schafer's previous games.  Then came the awesome end of Act I, and then Act II is pure awesomeness. The puzzles were multi-layered and fun, the characters were developed some more, and the game felt like it should have been like this from the start. So ultimately, I had a great time.  I would also like to praise the custom interface for all the different puzzles - this was done really well, much better than in many of the old adventure games, where this was always the biggest problem (  fighting the monster in Grim Fandango or racing in Full Throttle  ).

To put it bluntly, Broken Age is fantastic. The game is a classic point-and-click adventure, in the vein of the Lucasfilm Classics. For those of you who have been living under a rock for two years, Broken Age (previously known as Double Fine Adventure) was a huge kickstarter success, finishing up with over 3 million in crowd-sourced funds. Being one of the original big Kickstarter projects, there was some worry, but Double Fine pulled through in the most stylish way possible.  The game is split into two parts, which is.... split into another two parts. This is a review of Act 1. Act 2 will be released some time this year, and here's hoping it's as good as this act. In each act there are two tales to play, both incredibly different, but linked in many, many ways. In one, you play as Vella, a girl forced into tradition. In the other you play as Shay, a boy forced to stay in a spaceship his whole life. Both stories are incredibly fun to play.   On your first playthrough you may not notice the similarities between the stories, but if you think about them and put the events together in your mind, you realise how linked these tales are. I can't describe the amazing feeling I had when I discovered these connections. I can't really describe them without completely spoiling the game though.  The gameplay is what you would expect from any adventure game. It's fun, puzzling and satisfying. The only downfall is the sheer simplicity of the puzzles. I only really got stuck on one puzzle and even then it's because I just didn't notice one item amongst the background. However, this is actually a pro for younger gamers, as they will enjoy it without getting frustrated.  The art. Oh man, the art. It's gorgeous. I can say no more, just look at the screenshots.  The music is fantastic as in most Double Fine games. Some great peaceful, ambient tunes to relax you as the gears in your head grind.  The story is obviously great, with some excellent writing. The biggest caveat in adventure games for me is feeling bored as lines and lines of text go on and on. In this game though, I was always interested, clicking on every dialogue option available. The AAA voice acting helps a lot too. Before you ask, yes, Jennifer Hale is in it.  Overall, Broken Age is a must-buy. Generally I don't preorder or buy games at launch, I just wait for a sale. But this time I did and it was worth every dollar. The length may be an issue, but for me just Act 1 was worth the purchase, but with another act on the way, there's really no reason not to buy this ASAP.   What more can I say? Brilliant art, music, puzzle design, writing, voice acting.... It all helps to make this a great, great game. Do yourself a favour and pick this up. You won't regret it.

Pros: Amazing world, story, characters, twists. Cons: Act 2 was a quick connection to Act 1, story was short in Act 2, the wiring hexipal brought me to new levels of frustration.   I believe that the budget was blown on Act 1. This could be why some of the same scenery, characters, and shortened story was all what was in Act 2.   To be honest I really don't feel bad that I played this game. I would say buy it on sale, try the puzzles and enjoy the story. Just wished there was more depth to the story between the characters to how the original idea was drawn out.  For all the people that gave it a thumbs down, I really believe you had more to say about the game rather than what it had to offer. Take it for what it is and enjoy the story. Thanks to the team at Double Fine who made it all happen. Please keep this universe/game/genre going.

I'm sure my sentiments will be echoed across the internet, but I love this game.The visuals are a mix of artistic styles that are by turns childish, childlike, wondrous, and serene but each scene has edge to it that belies the games darker undertones. The surface is placid, but there are things stirring underneath. The voice acting is fantastic as well. There's a panoply of famous names, and I'm sure you'll know them when you hear them. Honestly I was surprised by Jack Black in what had to be his tamest performance yet. The first time I heard his character speak I was honestly put in mind of the character Arthur from the Journeyman project games, a character whom I love. I eventually realized it was Jack Black and for once, I didn't groan. Well done. The characters are diverse in temperament there was something similarly off about most of them. Not to ruin the story but a person who obstinately remains calm in the midst of mind wrenching horror is one of the scariest things I can think of. The banality of horror is truly chilling. Not to say this is a horror game, ho no! But keep in mind this is Tim Schaefer. He don't make games what don't have twisted sentiments. Gameplay was your standard Point und Klick Adventurwerks we all grew up on, but the inclusion of the drag and drop rather than clicks to use items really threw me for a while. I am very much used to the 'classic' controls-- ok the 'Non-textual input classic' controls-- I see you over there hipster gamer with your second-hand copy of Zork. Shut up before you attract a grue. I guess this was decided because they felt it more fit with The Tablet Set who are more used to drag and drop. The story is difficult to describe without spoiling it. Suffice to say it's great. I highly recommend it and I eagerly await its sequel.  A+

The only reason I recommend Broken Age is if you have children. I find it's too easy. There are points of the game where I snickered at the jokes or found somethings ironic to a point of being funny, but nothing really got me excited to play this. The puzzles didn't feel very challenging and the characters and jokes almost made me feel as though I was playing through a family film.  The music, voice-overs, and art are astounding; so, if you're into highproduction adventure games, this game is for you. I bought it because of Tim Schafer and to be quite honest, there's so much character that comes out this game, it was too hard to say no.   Perhaps I'll look at it again once the second chapter comes out, in hopes that the ending of the game becomes more 'serious'.

This game isn't flawless. I'll get the cons out of the way first: -The game suffers from one of my pet peeves in point and click games, the character 'magically' knows which items it can or can't interact with and which items will save a purpouse later on. if you can click on something and pick it up, your character's not gonna dare part with it until it eventually needs to use it for something. -There is a part in the second half of the game where the two characters need to perform actions based on the other characters' knowledge, even though there is no interaction between them. You can write this off as them acting on instinct or guessing, but... It probably could've been written better.  Pros: -Y'know, I could honestly care less about this game's gameplay faults because at it's core, it's a story. You're here for the plot, for the characters, and for the worldbuilding. And it excels at those. It's a truly good story, which is occasionaly paused when you hit a puzzle that you have a hard time solving. -There are also stuff I liked about the gameplay, but as I said, this game should be played mostly for the story it tells and the world it takes place in.

Broken Age has set out to revive our love for point-and-click adventure games - titles such as Grim Fandango, Monkey Island, and the like. Have Double Fine delivered on this front? Personally, the answer is a resounding 'YES'.  The art style, although rather simplistic upon first inspection, really adds to the overall feel of the game. The voice acting is top-notch, and the story (as far as I have experienced in Act 1) is riveting as you move from place to place, even room to room.  One minor flaw is that the puzzles aren't as challenging as I would have liked. Saying that, they are aiming to bring this genre to a wider audience and for that I can not really fault them.  I for one can't wait for Act 2. I highly recommend this title, even at full price.

I just finished my first playthrough of Broken Age, and I felt compelled to come write a review.  This game is one of the best adventure games I have ever played, and this is coming from a person who grew up with the genre. I am a big fan of Double Fine and all of their excellent work, and Broken Age shines as one of the best releases from a company who still continues to put their hearts and souls into their games.  With exceptional art, a touching and well written story (with quite a few unexpected twists!), and clever puzzles that provide a decent challenge while never tricking you with illogical solutions, I highly recommend Broken Age to any adventure fan.

I am a novice of the 2d graphic adventure genre. This is basically my first real foray into this world. I have played other adventure titles, like the Telltale games, and Ron Gilbert's recent release THE CAVE, yet this is my first real taste of Tim Schafer's distinct style. So with that being said please understand my expectations may differ from those who have played the vaunted Lucas titles, and have an affinity for that type of gameplay. For me though, this game was just a delight. Starting with the basics, the visuals in this game are unlike anything I have seen in a game. The use of these warm, wholesome colors, and these weird and off-kilter shapes and designs creates a distinct and wholly unique visual vocabulary, that just grabs you from second one, and never lets you go. And the way Tim Schafer's dialogue compliments that visual design is just spot-on. Really irreverent and dry humor gives way to some hilarious and unforeseen non-sequiturs that just lend itself so nicely to the feeling of familiarity and at the same time, mystery of this world. The music and voice-acting are also huge strengths. Everyone is really on-point with their line readings, and all the actors seem perfectly cast, and organic to the universe. The music drifts, almost like the wind, in the background of the game. Providing an eerie, almost ethereal quality to the game. But it can turn on a dime, and become the bombastic and self-important score of a summer blockbuster, which helps to highlight some of the more intense and larger-than-life moments. Now, all of this stuff combined would be enough for me to recommend it to anyone, but it is the gameplay that really puts this one into the stratosphere for me. The puzzle design, while sometimes subject to archaic tropes of the genre, is generally fantastic. The character inventory never gets so out-of-hand that I was banging my head on the wall for a solution, but not so easy that I was able to just breeze through it. The real process of solving was more reliant on your knowledge of each screen in a given area, and all the interactables in each screen. Limiting inventory allows you to focus more on the environment and less on the interactions of items you have in your possession. The puzzles difficulty was definitely ramped up in the second act, and sometimes there were ways to solve a puzzle that I felt weren't telegraphed in a way that made them readily apparent. But I was able to overlook those, as most of the puzzles were pretty self-evident, and required a little more than a modicum of thought to solve. Overall, I found this game to be one of my more cherished gaming experiences in recent memory. There were so few obvious flaws, and so few sour notes that I would be remiss if I did not recommend it to anyone who has even a tertiary interest in graphic adventure games. A nice, succinct, and gloriously original experience from the people at Double Fine. Great work!

Broken Age mixes a wonderful story of two perfect strangers chosen to fulfill a great destiny with beautiful hand-painted aesthetics to create one of the best graphic adventures of all time.  Divided in two acts (one which came out February 2014, the other April 2015) you control both characters in different environments, having the ability to switch between them at any given time. Sometimes, the actions from one affect the other, which makes some of the puzzles hard and compelling.  The story itself is amazing, one the best I've ever seen. Combining sci-fi with fantasy, finally creating one of the best atmospheres you could imagine for this kind of game.  Totally recommended.  ___________________________________  Original review Posted: 20 Feb, 2014 @ 7:38pm  'Broken Age's only flaw is being episodic. Well, not even a flaw. I mean, I just want to play the rest of it NOW! Hand painted graphics, wonderful performance, perfect gameplay, compelling story, and top-notch voice acting. What else do you want in a videogame?  A prime example of how Double Fine excels at videogame making, and how a really good graphic adventure is done. I can't wait for the rest of it to get released!  If you like having cliffhangers and enjoy the wait, you should get it now, if not then wait for the rest of the episodes and then get it. It's a superb graphic adventure, and a magnificent piece of art in every sense, in graphics, story, screenwriting, voice acting and gameplay mechanics.'

8/10: A nicely stylized point-and-click adventure about a boy and a girl from two different lifestyles realizing they aren't as worlds apart as it seemed. Nothing says 'evil' like social Darwinism!   Broken Age is Tim Schafer's Kickstarter success, a point-and-click experience that allows the player to switch between two young protagonists. Vella from Sugarbunting is a plucky young girl who has been chosen for The Maiden's Feast, which is a ritualized virgin sacrifice to a monster named Mog Chothra that supposedly keeps the creature from raining destruction down on the town. Shae, a young dude, is trapped in a juvenile routine on a spaceship at the overprotective behest of MOM, and yearns for anything resembling real adventure.   Needless to say, Vella doesn't take her impending sacrifice lying down, and Shae goes out of his way to find some real action. Without getting too far into spoiler territory, this derails the long-standing ritual and reveals that both of their roles served a far different purpose than they originally believed, and that those responsible for their respective scenarios are the true antagonist(s).   All of this is experienced in the typical point-and-click fashion as you wander about, picking up various objects and discerning how exactly they can help you overcome your current roadblock. Sometimes the answer is obvious, occasionally it's unclear, and in some cases you have to switch between the characters to find the solutions you need, but the game rarely leaves the player grasping at straws for the solution, especially since making mistakes will at times reveal a hint for figuring out the right move.   Basically, it's a good story and a fun game to experience for a few hours. It may not outrank Psychonauts on my Tim Schafer game list, but it's definitely among the better works of Double Fine.

Review for Act 1  While playing video games growing up I've come to realize that the best games always seem to have something very specific in common; something that allows you get wrapped up in and immersed in a different world to escape reality for a short time and get lost in the beauty of it; and that would be that they all have a great story. A story first above all else; above crazy graphics, above gameplay, and even above music, etc. A story that lets you become a part of it.  There are so many games these days that seem to forget that you should always start with that good story first, with fully realized worlds and the characters that inhabit them. And the games that do realize what should come first, usually turn out to be amazing works of art; games that draw you in and never let go, and have a lasting impression. And Broken Age is an excellent example of this. The story is at the heart of the experience and you can feel it.  And even though this game might seem very simplistic in nature (given its gameplay style), it truly is just as satisfying to play as it would be to play a huge, multi-million dollar, RPG production made by a first-party studio by hundreds of people. But I think that's what makes this game so special: that it can be as great as it is even though it was made by just a handful of dedicated people who truly care about what they’re creating and why they’re creating it.  Double Fine has shown that you can have an exciting adventure that whisks you away to worlds full of challenges, laughter, and even emotionally-engaging moments, in the form of a point-and-click adventure that’s very accessible and easy to pick up and play. And the impact you feel at the end of Act 1 is an immensive one, that really gets you thinking. It was surprising to find out how much I cared about what happened to the two main characters and how they impacted the worlds around them.  I would definitely recommend this game to people who enjoy a great story, even if the gameplay style isn’t normally what they might be in to. You just might be surprised with how much you’ll enjoy it.  I absolutely cannot wait until Act II! I cannot wait to go back into Shay's and Vella's worlds to finally get some answers to some burning questions! And I have a feeling it's going to be a very satisfying conclusion regardless of how it ends.  :)  Congrats again to Double Fine for some amazing work so far!

I'm not a huge fan of point and click adventure games. I worry about esoteric puzzles and mistakes that could make the game unbeatable.   With that said, I loved Broken Age! Admittedly, it did have some pretty tough puzzles in the latter half. But for all that, the story was awesome, and it left an impression on me. I can't imagine I'll have another experience like it.  And my tree-related jokes repetoire is up, so that's a nice bonus.

--- DISCLAIMER: This review is written by someone who, obviously, was a backer to the project. As well, it must be noted that only the first half of the game is playable.---  After a long wait, the game that truly kickstarted the Kickstarter games craze is out - well, half of it, for now. I liked it.  While it certainly has a more streamlined approach to point-and-click gaming, Broken Age does have the charm that reminded me of that golden age of graphical adventure games, back in the 90s. The character design is delicously original, the storyline starts slow but develops deeper themes of alienation and absence of control over one's own life, the storybook-style visuals are evocative and beautiful, the orchestral music is simply stellar, and most of the cast does a magnificent job of breathing life into their characters - with a special mention going to Jennifer Hale as 'Mother'.  Inventory management is stripped to the bare essentials, and there is no use of verbs or actions - think Telltale Games, not early 90s Sierra or LucasArts. But this stripped-down design does not turn the game into a simple QTE-fest. At its heart, it is still an adventure game, with all the backtracking, item-hunting, and puzzle-solving that is involved. Besides, most adventure games of old may have had multiple verbs and actions available, but most items and interactable objects in the games were usually a one-way thing: if you didn't select the exact right verb or the exact right item, you simply couldn't do anything with said item. Thus, freed from useless time-wasting devices, the game can concentrate on its storyline. And while the first part, so far, may seem short, let's remember that you could finish classic adventure games like Monkey Island 2 in less than two hours.  Some will nevertheless be disappointed, but after nearly two years of development, there wasn't much that Tim and his gang could have done to satisfy the tallest expectations from the hordes hungry for a Double Fine Adventure. But make no mistake, Broken Age, so far, is a gem.

The game is great up until the end. That whole ending puzzle was a mess and the story ending was too abrupt and unsatisfactory. I guess they'll need more funding to finish the story. Act three I suppose? Still worth buying on sale though.

Really happy about how Act 1 turned out. Tim and his team produced a stunning result with a charming art direction an interesting story and fun characters brought to life by the excellent voice acting. The only thing about a little bit disappointed about is that the puzzles aren't really challenging and involve any out of the box thinking like in previous games. Additionally there are sadly no new twists on the point & click genre so the whole game feels very 'safe'. But don't get me wrong this doesn't make the game bad or anything. The formular works and doesn't distract from the whole experience. This game is easily recommendable to any point & click adventures fan.

The game is great up until the end. That whole ending puzzle was a mess and the story ending was too abrupt and unsatisfactory. I guess they'll need more funding to finish the story. Act three I suppose? Still worth buying on sale though.

Don't expect Broken Age to be similar to Lucasarts great games, with weird characters and hilarious jokes everywhere. Don't expect Broken Age to be a very deep point and click with difficult puzzles.  Do expect Broken Age to be as soft as its wonderful, pastel-colored world. The humor is there, but it's chuckles and light touches, instead of being a in-your-face laughing out loud thing. The game has a deeper goal than simply making you laugh, so it toned down the humor Do expect Broken Age to tell you a story instead of stumping you on puzzles. Puzzles are easy, but that serve to make the story and the exploration more enjoyable.  If you go without theses assumptions, you will discover a charming game, in a wonderful world, that is begging for you to explore it more. It's a story more than a game, and I love it for that. Unfortunately, this is only Act 1, and it ends on a cliffhanger that is hinting at a very surprising Act 2...Can't wait to know the end of that story :)
Everything about Broken Age made me smile. A truly lovely game with gorgeous visuals, great music, and a great story. Broken Age was worth the wait.

First and foremost, there is a *huge* amount ……… of charme – established by the visuals,  character design, voice acting and camera ……… work. But where is the substance?  Unlike in classical LucasArts adventure games ……… – where walking about alone with the  occasional 'Pick up Item' was not enough to ……… solve the puzzles and demanded further  thinking & experimenting – traversing the areas ……… in the same manner in BA already  solves half the puzzles. This results in a ……… short & easy game. It does have charme but lacks the humor quality typical of Tim.  Playing as either of two characters and ……… switching to them at will spices the game  up a bit, but as short as this is there isn't ……… much sense for this feature altogether, imo.

Before finally buying this game, I had my doubts with the constant amount of negative reviews I saw. However, when finally buying it, alongside with the soundtrack, I didn't understand why there's so much negativity to the game. The art style is more than creative, the writing is unique like most of Tim Schafer's games I've played, the voice acting was something that felt just right, and the overall gameplay was fun. The entire experience was something I enjoyed from beginning to end. Of course there were times where I got stuck in between a few puzzles, but that's the nice challenge I received that kept me maintaining a nice incentive rather than an easy play through. However, I do have to admit that this game isn't for everybody, and that's fine. Although, if you have a desire for something creative and new, this is a neat little gem you'll that I recommend buying on sale and maybe even on its normal price.  9.5/10: I'll play it some time again.

I recommend this, and I hope original and inspired games like this keep getting made by talented and hard working studios like Double Fine.   Great ending to Act 1, and I can't wait for more. I really enjoyed my time with this game. It was short, but I knew it would be going in. The humor and great game design that have been in past DoubleFine games is here and as excellent as ever. If you've enjoyed DoubleFine games in the past, you'll enjoy this too.
Great game so far, it's not very long but the story's awesome.
A beautiful and modern take on the adventure genre that I grew up with. As a backer, I can definitely say that this was money well spent!
It's almost like adventure games were never gone.
This is one of the most beautiful games that I've ever played.
Not perfect, but worth your time.

Best game I have ever played. story and art are just amazing, puzzles difficulty was spot on! even though Act 1 is Better than Act 2, Act 2 is still a one of a kind masterpiece. I have no words to describe Act 1, I feel in love with it right away, Double Fine have managed to perfect every element in it.  In conclusion, Broken Age is a one of a kind experience that every Point & Click gamer who knows a thing or two, should have.

Broken Age is a fun and simple point & click with decent writing, that cool Tim Schaffer art style akin to Psychonauts and interesting puzzles. It's good for about 2.5-3.5 hours of gameplay depending on your playstyle. The story is intriguing with good pacing especially at the beginning of Shays story where it beats you to death with Shays boring monotanous routine but this serves a purpose once you start exploring which I suppose adds some depth to the game. Then there's the female protagonist Vella, who starts the game in a somewhat precarious situation that she must escape from which later ties the fate of the two protagonists together in a twist ending. 8/10
This game is awesome. Just...just play it already.

A wonderfully fun game that I enjoyed thoroughly. From the hand-painted backgrounds to the superb voice acting, I can't recommend this game highly enough. I am now eagerly awaiting Part 2 and it can't come soon enough! 10/10

Awesome Game.  Funny, original, intriguing story and characters.  My only problem comes from the fact that it's not finished yet, waiting for act 2. I don't really get why they wouldn't finish it before lauching it.
An unbelievable story with great art and an ending that left me dying for more!

What a wonderful point and click adventure. Was watching development of this unfold after purchasing the indie bundle with the Broken Age Backer addition in it. I'm a sucker for these types of games, and this one was refreshingly different. The voice acting was great, and the music was wonderfully charming.   If you are looking for a casual thing to play with lots of charm and personality, this will be fun for you. I cannot wait for Act II!
Point, click, drag and drop! What else do you need to know???
Great 4 hours (Act 1)!

I enjoyed playing this game a great deal. The dialogue is funny and thoughtful, the characters are fascinating, and the artwork is beautiful. The voice acting is brilliant! I tried to examine every aspect that was interactable and combine items as much as possible, and it took me around five hours to play through Act 1. More importantly, I enjoyed playing the game and I am very much looking forward to playing Act 2 when it is released.  Even more importantly, I made a tree vomit. It was great!

A classic story book come to life; in interactive glory! Have you ever wondered what your purpose in life is? Well join the cast of Broken Age, and find out the impact of their actions on the universe. You play the role of two unique characters, each with their own spellbinding and whimsical experiences. Also, in traditional double fine fashion, the characters are enjoyable and the dialog is pretty damn funny. The art appears as if it was done in chalk or other similar medium, which is a welcome addition to the narrative.
awesome game, can't wait for act 2
Great story telling, bad adventure game.
Simply amazing. A tear for Gary. Great job Tim and Double Fine. My personal GOTY 2014 and so far for 2015 as well. Really cannot wait to see what these guys do next!!
Tim Schafer is back better than ever and he brought along with him a meticulously hand-crafted point-and-click masterpiece in Broken Age.

I waited until both acts were out, then played the whole thing, and loved it!  That's not to say it's flawless... there's a significant amount of running from one end of the world to the other and back; one puzzle had me completely stuck until a walkthrough told me the solution was written somewhere in the other character's perspective, which is really dumb; another makes you repeat a bunch of steps if you make a mistake at all.  But overall, I really liked it. It looks and sounds gorgeous, it's funny, and I enjoyed the story.
Loved Act 1! Act 2 is taking too long though.

I was first drawn to this game because of how nice the hand-painted graphics were, it was one of those games that I purchase because of some completely superficial reason over the aesthetically pleasing graphics. I just finished playing a game and I was thinking of which one to try next, so I picked this game, because it looked like it would be nice and short.   When I started playing it, it was almost nothing that I expected, the only exception being the graphics. For the first few minutes the absurdity and childishness of both of the protagonists decor was quite deterring, but after learning of the background it became quite atmospheric and fitting. The decor only helped to further the air of being plunged into the insanity that the other characters created.  As the game progresses more and more twists intrigue you to continue further in the game and to find out more. The puzzles can be quite tedious in some parts, but they can easily be conquered with a guide or some hints from the internet, if you don't feel like completing them yourself.   This game was for quite a long time in the making, but the end product is worth the wait and now that it is finished the long wait is merely the past. I would also suggest that you don't wait through the credits unless you either backed the kickstarter or you find usernames amusing.  Broken Age is a great game that if you ever get the chance or ever become intrigued by it, you should buy and play it, it's worth the money and the time.

Broken Age is not for those looking for a challenging adventure game but if you miss the old point and click adventure games this will satisfy that appetite. Not all the puzzles are challenging and some of them don't even require any work but what Broken Age lacks in complexity it makes up for it, with a wonderful story set in a strange and interesting world. I'm looking forward to see what Double Fine gives us in the next chapter.
Act 2 is mess. It's not a satisfying end at all. Act 1 ended on good potential... then Act 2 dropped it, stepped on it, scraped it up and put it out the door over a year later.
Perfect for you in the  broken age  of Steam backlogs.
The puzzles lack of any logical sense and the story seems to drop in quality after chapter 2

Yes it's short. I beat it in around three hours. However, this is only the first act. The game is amazing, nailing it's voice acting, script, and comedy down easily. It's puzzles are simple, and you don't have to think TOO hard, however that's not the main point. I'd have to say though, you'd probably be better off buying it when act 2 comes out.

It's a really fun play. The styles pretty and colorful and the characters cool to learn about. You really grow with them. The only bad part is the length. It definately feels like half a game. Only buy it when its on sale, since it's definately not worth 25$ That being said I'm probably going to buy the second one (once its on sale) when it comes out.

It disturbs me to learn that not only is Tim on the wrong side of Gamer Gate, but that he is also pulling the Anita stunt with raising a ton of money to do something low-budget over a long period of time. With that said, I honestly enjoyed what he's done so far with the game. Broken Age has pleasing artwork, tricky puzzles (not as hard as some point-and-click adventures I've played), a good story and soundtrack. They ending to the first Act has left me pretty pepped for the next one, however I'd be pretty disappointed if the second act is the rest of the game, assuming it's as long as the first act.   Here's a message for Tim Shcafer: I expect from you not a Fine game, not a Double Fine game, but a TRIPLE Fine game. You've been in the business long enough. Put your back into it and make Broken Age your best game yet!

i wish there was a neutral button, this is it, the story is ok ish, but it is a p;oint and click in every way. be prepared to be frustrated at your logic being wrong and they you spend 20 mins trying to use everything with everything.
A nice first try from this dev, they have a bright future ahead of them if they can just get rid of the story guy.
Broken Age is a 2D Point & Click Adventure by Double Fine, the same crew who brought you Grim Fandango Remastered, another P&C game which I also happened to review recently.   Storyline
I enjoyed this game and my 6 year old loves it too! It was nice that he and I could interact and talk about a game that isn't all cuts and gore.

Weird and beautiful. The story is like none I've heard of.  There are two worlds. In one world (a primitive and rural country village) you control the girl; in the other (hi-tech sci-fi mothership) - the boy. The events happen in the same time frame.  The graphics resemble an oil painting. Weird and beautiful. The soundtrack is not bad, either.  Warning: the second part becomes more... technical. The puzzles rely heavily on mathematical logic.

As one who did not grow up with point and click adventure games, I had a lot of fun with Broken Age Act 1. The puzzles were clever, but not too mind bending, and it didn't take to long to figure anything out. It was an enjoyable experience. The art in the game is impressive as well. The style is captivating. Easy on the eyes and detailed where it needs to be. The animations were fantastic. They really brought the chatacters to life, as did the voice work. Every character felt real, which is an impressive feat compared to what some bigger games have done. You can tell that Double Fine devoted a lot of time to each character to make each one feel like a person, and I love every line of dialogue you can get out of them.   HOWEVER, as much fun as I had with Broken Age, there is a HUGE caviat I have to put forward. As a $15 Backer of the project, I most certainly am happy with what I paid and what I got, knowing full well that there's more to come. $22.49, in my opinion, is much too steep a price at this stage. I finished Act 1 in under four hours. While it was fun and extremely well executed, I would be extremely disapointed paying that much for this game in its current state.   So while a fantastic work, I personally don't believe that the current price is justified. I'd say wait for a sale, or wait for Act 2. I would not pay $22.49 for what I just played. It was a fun adventure with great atmosphere and a neat story, but I can't recommend it now for this price unless you REALLY enjoy the genre.   I honestly wish I could give this game a neutral rating.
This game is great! bring on Act 2!!!
An amazing game, totally worth it. It relies on choices and overall gives you a good laugh. Although it is eerie at times.
I'm free to cleave the inifinite void of space itself!
This game is awesome.
'It's pretty' is the only nice thing that can be said about this mess.
Where the ♥♥♥♥ is Part 2? 'A few months after Act 1...' was what Tim said.

Excellent graphics, with smooth animation that never takes you out of the storybook visuals. Excellent voice-acting as well. But the puzzles are too simple, the game is too short, and the characters aren't quite as fleshed out as I would have liked. There was much potential here for some rich storytelling and character development, but sadly that is all missing. I hope Act 2 delivers. The game as it stands is pleasant enough, but more memorable for its graphics than anything else.

This game is way too short. 4 hours of gameplay tops. Definitely not worth it unless you can get top discount. Only worth it if they release the second act similar way to Telltale Games episode-system, if not again definitely not worth it.  The game is funny, cute and really well made. The voice work is solid and the art style is certainly unique if a bit of an acquired taste. The puzzles are simple and straight forward. Well aside for one which you have to walk in the right spot. Everything else in the game is simply solid, except the duration.  I wish steam had a third option regarding recommendation. My 'no' comes with reservations: Get it when cheap or get it if you are OK with a very short gaming experience. Otherwise don't bother.
This game was very good. The art is amazing and I hadn't stumbled across anything that is needed for improvement. I'm so excited for part 2!!!

Leaving aside the fact that the game is not complete, and likely won't be complete until at least Spring of 2015 at the earliest (and, given history, probably will slip into the summer), what has been delivered so far just isn't too interesting. It doesn't know if it wants to be horrifying, surreally funny or inspiring, and just becomes a mess. The story is pretty simplistic with an utterly predictable twist at the end of act 1, the characters fairly uninteresting and the characterizations incredibly shallow.  Do not buy in its current state. Opinions may change when the game is finally finished, but until then, this is just a middling, uninspired adventure game that's maybe half done.

Broken Age is otherworldly in theme and overall cute. Short of a few moments I would get stuck on how to progress the game the experience was entirely smooth and relaxing. I definintly enjoyed playing it.   The downside is as soon as things between teh two characters you play start tying together the game suddenly throws a curveball that makes them make any sense that came of the brief meeting suddenly make no sense again before it abruptly ends; 'End of Act 1' and 'To be continued' it claims. I basically played until I reached the end of act one in a single sitting, put it down, then picked it up the next day intending to continue just to find out that was technically the end of the game.  I liked the game, but it was so short. It has awesomely imaginative themes involved but it intends for you to buy each act seperately from what I can tell - unless it's just an incomplete game at the moment that automatically downloads the next act when completed (shot in the dark. I haven't researched it).   It's worth a play. It's a quick play though.

Oh wow. Double Fine actually managed to make a game that has so much wit and humour in it that it deserves a place alongside the stellar LucasArts adventures of old.  I am too shocked, bewildered, excited and enamoured to nitpick, even though I probably could. Even if Act II flops, the game has already managed to tug at more heartstrings of mine than any other game I've played in a while.

Broken Age relies on its unique art-style, modernised adventure game interface, and likeable (but still somewhat dark!) story and characters to be so great. I'm so glad this was Kickstarted. Only one Act is out so far, and it's not especially long, but that doesn't matter when the quality is as high as this game. Admittedly, I needed to use a walkthrough at a few small points (moreso to find where an item is than to solve any of the puzzles, which are all fairly reasonable).
Refreshing, sweet, and a little challenging, this little game was a great deal of fun to play. I loved the art style, as well. Highly recommended.
If you don't buy this game you're a dummy.

Every single artistical aspect of this game is great, but puzzles are a bit to easy and gameplay straightforward. All in all is a joy to play if you want to relax and enjoy a beautiful story. Beware: currently you buy only the Act I of the adventure, Act II will be out in the near future (I hope).

When I first heard about Broken Age I immediately added it into my Wishlist hoping it made an appearance during the Flash Sale. I was in luck when I bought this at $8.50 because I didn't receive any notification. After completing it I absolutely recommend it but I would suggest to wait for sale. For a few hours of play at the $24.99 price tag you may find yourself wanting more content for the buck.  That being said Broken age was charming and kept you engaged.The art style was bright, playful and beautiful. The gameplay reminded me of other casual games where you searched for an item and tried to figure out it's use to progress the storyline. If anyone has played any Hidden Object or Puzzle adventure games you can understand how frustrating and rewarding it could be at times. During parts of Broken Age there weren't many items to look for and that's when it was more of like an interactive story. As for the characters, the voice acting from a star lineup was incredible and I couldn't find one character I didn't like. Rare, if you ask me for these types of games its typical for some to fall flat. If you are looking for a great story and a casual gaming experience you can cozy up to please consider this game. I can't wait for Act II.
The artwork in this game is amazing along with the acting. I enjoyed every minute playing this game
the art in this is amazing. this is something you don't want to pass up. do a favor for your eyes.
This is a lot of fun. The most enjoyable point and click I've played since Machinarium. I love the two storylines, it's basically like having two separate adventure games.
This is an amazing game that helps bring back the point-and-click adventure genre. I can't wait for Act 2.

As usual, DoubleFine and Tim Schafer do not disappoint. Everything about this game is awesome, from the intriguing, interwoven storylines, to the unique and well-developed characters, to the scenery and voice acting and soundtrack, and just. Ugh. What an great game. Can't wait for Act 2!
This game was both fun and beautiful, full of memorable characters and places, and interesting puzzles. Left me wanting more but super excited for part 2~!
Wow, amazing game .-. can't wait for the next one.
I had the biggest grin on my gace whilst playing this beautifully cradted game. The story and characters so far have been excellent, I can't wait to see how it all develops in the second act.

Disclaimer: This review is going to consider only Act 1 of the game. This does not, however, regard the game's price, as Act 2 isn't included yet, but will be released soon for free.  Many people are complaining about the length of the game compared to its price at the moment, and as such are not recommending the game. I don't think that's fair, because the first half of the game is about four hours and 30 minutes long, so I'm expecting at least 8-9 hours of gameplay once Act 2 is released. (End Disclaimer)  Broken Age is a game with two co-existing stories that are set in   seemingly   seperate worlds. One story follows Vella, a girl from the bakery town of Sugar Bunting who has been selected to be sacrificed to a monster known as Mog Chothra as part of the town's 'maiden feast'- which is apparently a great honor- and ultimately chooses to escape the event in search of a way to kill the beast. The other story centers on Shay, a boy who is alone on a sentient spaceship that takes care of him, and more importantly, keeps him safe. Shay, however, is bored of the childish, mundane routine that the ship puts him through every day to keep him entertained, and discovers that the ship's AI has been lying to him, which sets him on a quest to take control of the ship himself.
