Broken Age plays as a point-and-click adventure game; in most situations, you click areas you want to move to or investigate, ask questions from NPCs to figure out what to do or where to go, solve puzzles, collect items, use items to solve more puzzles, and most importantly, discover the world and immerse yourself in the story of the world. The game allows you to transition from Vella's and Shay's stories at any time via. the Inventory Window, so if you get stuck on a puzzle in one world, you can switch to the other for a while so you can continue playing the game without getting super frustrated. There are many ways to use this system to fit your playing preferences; you can switch the stories regularly, you can switch the stories when you get stuck on a character, or you can just play through one character at a time as you wish.  Overall, the game feels pretty good- that is, the game flows for me. If I click an area farther away, the characters will run to the target, whereas if I click an area closer to me, the characters will walk. The camera-work feels right for the most part, however sometimes the inventory will pop up if I move the cursor too close to the bottom left of the screen, especially when a place I want to click is located near that location. Cutscenes are generally done through a close-up view of the characters as they speak, and the animations during the cutscenes are fun and captivating. I'm never terribly confused as to what an item in my inventory does, as clicking on them without dragging them on anything gives me a decent description of the item. Sometimes, dragging certain items towards certain characters results in a fun(ny) interaction between the player character and the respective other characters. Generally, anything that is clickable that is not a walkable path presents useful or amusing information / dialogue about the objects when clicked. NPCs never feel totally boring to listen to, and if you are a faster reader than the voice acting (and happen to have subtitles on), you can skip any cutscenes by hitting space once or twice.   The illustration style is quirky, painterly, and well-done. It's also sometimes surreal, but there's nothing remarkably too creepy or unsettling generally found in surrealist paintings; if that's kind of your thing, you'll probably disagree with me on its surreality. As mentioned early, the characters are animated in a way that is fun and captivating, and it's fun to watch the characters move, even with their idle animations. The visual effects really make everything come together, from background objects rotating to in-game LED screens flashing words, to puffs of clouds kicking up as a chracter walks, they really help background elements feel more real and connected the characters that inhabbit the spaces.  The music is beautiful. (If you grab the soundtrack, I highly suggest listening to Vella and Shay's theme songs all the way through.) Overall, it really makes the atmosphere of the game come alive, especially with the cutscenes with songs that are scored into the game, or the ones that don't feature a lot (or any) interaction with the game itself, which sets up a nice cinematic feeling that, in my opinion, adds to the game rather than take away from it.  Some of the things I noted people complain about are the difficulty of the puzzles and the linearity of choices as you go through the game. While I recognize that the difficulty of the puzzles is low, and generally not super-challenging, I feel that for the sake of being only the first half the game, it definitely is better for those gamers who are not common adventure game players to ease into the logic of the game puzzles. Plus, I thought they were hard enough for most people to not realize immediately how to solve several of the puzzles, especially when the options are not immediately or obvious or sometimes overlooked for feeling they are a tad ridiculous. (In my experience, the more difficult puzzles took me much longer to figure out in comparison to the ones that were intentionally much easier. Additionally, I have to mention that not a lot of people realize the solution to one of the first puzzles in one of the stories until it's almost directly stated in the dialogue.)  In response to the linearity of choices as you go through the game, I feel like if you weren't given some sort of goal to work towards as you get through the game, many of the players would spend a lot of time in the game getting next to nothing done. I don't say this as if a game is meant to be beaten, but for a game heavily focused on the stories of two characters, it's not as if the fate of these characters are ultimately determined by what the player does in the game, but more by the story. To make my point clear; the reason some puzzles are presented to you at certain times if for the sake of story progression. You would be totally stuck if you didn't know what to at times. If the problem is less so linearity due to story progression and more the lack of extra things to do, well.... I don't think you realize this, but even this amount of content was super-expensive to make, and you wouldn't realize this if you hadn't been watching the Double Fine Adventure documentary (or, for that matter, have been interested in the games industry besides as a consumer in the first place).  It's not like I don't have any problems with the game at all; some important objects you need for puzzles blend into the background, or are looked over in the first few times you pass the area they're contained in. Some jokes fall flat, which is fine for the most part I suppose, because otherwise the dialogue is amazing for all reasons. As mentioned earlier, sometimes the camera placement results in clickable locations being located in the bottom-left corner of the screen, so the inventory likes to pop up and you'll wind up clicking an item instead of the intended location.  As mentioned earlier, this review doesn't take into account the amount of time you can play compared to it's price in it's current state. Also as mentioned, the game plays for about four hours and 30 minutes total, with about 2 hours and 15 minutes per character for a more experienced adventure gamer. If the rest of the game was canceled right now, I wouldn't suggest purchasing the game.   (This is less so for the length of the game in it's current state, but the fact that it ends at such a HUGE cliffhanger.)   However, Act 2 is being added for free soon, so I think the money's worth it.  I'm running out of characters; all-in-all, 9.5 / 10 from me, can't wait for Act 2. :)
Charming visuals, voiced by some fan favorites, and with a few interesting surprises.
Did you, do you like Myst? Then this should be another game on your list. Good puzzles, good story, lots of fun... especially when you realize how simple the answer was (after 2 hours of trying)...

Amazing game, great story and artwork. The game is a bit easy sometimes but the story makes up for it. If the game where too hard, the player could get annoyed and probably miss some of the story and then have problems understanding the storry later on. All in all it's a grat game and i can't wait for act 2.
Classic DoubleFine! Totally makes up for the debacle that was Spacebase DF9. *Shudders*

disagree with all the negative reviews. in my opinion Broken Age is the perfect game. and for a really low price. also I believe I received all I could possible expect as a backer of the Double Fine Adventure project - and more.

Fun game, great ending (of the first act). There is one puzzle which makes you go back to the whole previous area which sucks donkeyballs.  Note that only half of the game is available, the other half will come in an update during this year (hopefully).  EDIT: The puzzles in the second half of the game suck. Lots of backtracking, lots of not getting the timing right. I had to redo some puzzles multiple times even when I 100% knew the answer.  The final phase of the game is a mess.  The ending is very underwhelming.  After playing the second act, I suggest you stop playing after the first. It all goes downhill from there.
Part 1: Bloody lovely.  Part 2: Wiring puzzles. Clunky, slow. Badly written. Re-use all the assets! Ten times the trial and error! Moon logic! WIRING PUZZLES!

Beautifully written and entirely captivating, with wonderful artwork and great voice work, the game leaves you guessing until the last second. It's worth the purchase for act one alone.   I'm looking forward to the rest...  So it's been the bones of a year and a half since act one and the fundamentals are still great, the artwork and voice work are still on point, but after all that time I was hoping for more content.  The puzzles are relatively easy, there's a little bit of the 'combine this with that' mechanic, and after the half way mark there is a distinct element of needing to jump between stories to solve puzzles which was nice, but story wise doesn't make much sense, aside from their 'having a connection'. There is also this one puzzle specifically that was just annoying. It's obvious and you will do it a dozen times without it working to the point that it will actually take away from the game, but that's just the type of game it is.  The story promises a lot, and it really seems like it's going to payoff until the end where it just doesn't satisfy.   The game was fine, it entertained but I wanted so much more from the game than it delivered.  So yeah, nothing is broken, it's very pretty, the puzzles are relatively easy (a couple of notable exceptions aside) and the story after starting strong turns out to be nothing to write home about, if you want it wait for a sale.

It's no Secret of Monkey Island, Day of the Tentacle, Grim Fandango, Broken Sword, or Gabriel Knight. But it's pretty good. That said I'd recommend all of those games before this one. (Maybe Sam and Max hit the Road as well, but that one is more for the well written dry humor, not for the puzzles)

(Act 2) Don't play Act 2. It's literally just a poor mirror version of Act 1 with the same exact levels and puzzles with slightly new characters and infinitely more infuriating solutions. Stop at the cliffhanger halfway through the game and imagine your own ending.  (Act 1) I'll keep this short and sweet, because that's what Broken Age is. It's hilarious, somber, beautiful, always brilliant and never boring. It has characters that feel real and honest despite their children's storybook inspired looks, moments that can gut you with their sudden intensity and dark undertones, and - to be truly blunt - just one helluva finale (I am underselling this. It is... staggering). On the (only) downside: it's puzzles are either eye-rollingly easy or maddeningly vague, but the drive to see what hilarious dialogue tree will emerge from which bizarre character next is the carrot on the end of the stick here. To sum up: giant monsters, overprotective AI, sap-barfing trees, a cult in the sky, and a talking spoon whose one mission is to be stuck in your mouth. You really should just go play it already.
2nd half is garbage...

The return of Tim Schaffer, good ol adventure games of point and click. The man who made Full Throttle and co-designed and co-writed Maniac Mansion: Day of the Tentacle and Monkey Island 2. I was disapointed to wait for so long for the Part 2 of Broken Age. Plus the achievements came in after i completed the first part so had to replay all of the first part, bummer. But this is a great game after all, puzzles are not that easy. You will need to save and reload a couple of places to get some flawless achievements. The graphics are very nice and full voices.

I found Broken Age through the Double Fine Adventure series. I've always loved behind the scenes documentaries about creative enterprises like movies and games. So I much more interested in the process than they actual game. But I quickly reached a point where DFA made me so interested in the project that I had to stop, buy the game and play through before I finished DFA.   I haven't play an adventure game in more than a decade, so I came to Broken Age without the nostalgia people have for Monkey Island or Grim Fandango.   But within ten minutes I was in. The art style is gorgeous, the story is compelling, and the twist at the end of Act I was fantastic.   The puzzles in Act II were beyond my frustration tolerance for an enjoyable experience and if it were a different game I would have put it down. But the story and the art style completely got it's hooks into me that I had to finish it, even though it meant leaning on a walkthrough from time to time. It is a great accomplishment for the studio that was further enriched by the documentary.   Thanks to Tim Schaffer and all the folks at Double Fine for giving one of my best gaming experiences of the year.

I grew-up playing adventure games. The HYPE around this one made a lot of promises. However, it like most early release/crowd funded games lost its way. The first half of the game was better then the second. If the plot and game design was completed before the funding, it might have been a better game. You could see the break in continuity of designing on the fly. All in all... the story was average at best.(maybe a little below) Better luck next time.  Graphics: Interesting Music: Good Voice acting: Very good Control: Good Puzzles: Meh Plot: Interesting(First half), Really?(Second half)  Suggested ages: 8 to 12
Very fun can't wait for act 2. Great story that will leave you hanging. Come on ACT2!!
Parrt 1 was awesome ^^ Part 2 was pain in the ♥♥♥:P
Very creative point-click game
Nice Art-Style and charming story, i really like it. Feel like an old time Classic Point-And-Click Adventure!

Unlike most people here, I found the entirety of this game - yes, even Act 2 - rather charming, even if it was largely for the art. I do agree that it doesn't quite have the brilliant feel of games such as Grim Fandango, but up until the middle, it holds its own quite well.  Act 1 was quite fun to play through. While the puzzles were easy, I feel that they were more assets to the storytelling rather than a major drawing point, and I loved the twist at the end. Each story was completely independant from the other, so if you really wanted to you could, say, finish Vella's side before even starting Shay's (a feature missing from Act 2). Another point in favor of Act 1 is that it was funny - in the very least enough to provoke a smile.  Ok, despite what I said earlier, Act 2 was a bit hit-and-miss, at least partially because of the episodic nature of the game which ended up breaking the flow of the story. The puzzles - especially the first one of Vella's side - had me clicking back and forth, wishing there was more varied dialouge as the same few lines repeated again and again and again. The story isn't [i ]bad, [/i] per se - it is not as good as Act 1's, but for me the revelation that    the sun was a person    somewhat ruined my enjoyment as it felt almost completely out of the blue and I still don't really understand why    she acted like a computer for however many years of Shay's life, or how she keeps her hair so... poofy. So, so poofy.     My advice would be that if this game is on sale, get it. Play it up to the end of Act 1, and if you play on, close the game and pretend Act 2 wasn't a thing.  If you've already played Act 2, replay Act 1 and pretend Act 2 wasn't a thing. I love this game, honestly, and I'm a massive fan of Double Fine and I mean no offence to them, but can we deny Act 2's existance for the good of everyone who might want to play this game, the devs... and probably ourselves?

Act 1 is actually brilliant and well developed, I was totally emerged in the world and the two protagonists. That did make me quite anticipated playing Act 2. However, the puzzle in the late game actually force the player out of the characters and the world. But the worst thing is about the ENDING!! That is actually one of the most frustrating moment for me in gaming. (If not the most!) It ended so awkwardly that you might shout: What the heck just happened!? (If not worst...)  Pros: Awesome Arts, Characters, Conversation and Story (especially in ACT 1 , and these are mostly the things you want in a point and click adventure game in my opinion.) Cons: Lazy implemented puzzle in late game AND Extremely Bad Ending(which is the most important thing in this genre in my opinion)  If you can make up a good ending for youself and ignore what the game showed to you, go ahead and play it. Otherwise, prepare for the worst when you play it.

I played Broken Age with my wife. She's new to adventure games, but I've loved them for years. I found the puzzles a bit easy (the dead eye was a bit tricky), but my wife was sufficiently challenged -- so maybe I just know the ways of adventure games too well.  Broken Age is beautiful, well acted, nicely animated, funny, and everything else you could want in an adventure game. The first act is a bit short, but the second act has some good length.  I'd recommend it to anyone except someone who really hates classic adventure games (while it's not as obscure as they used to be, it's pretty faithful in a lot of good ways).
Great game

An excellent game! Great music, loveable and believeable characters and lots of subtle and not so subtle humor. When hours of playtime are passing by without you realising it, you know you're hooked. This is it. 10/10  EDIT (some months later): The second part fell flat, to be honest. But the first one, even as a standalone could very well end on its cliffhanger and play the end out in your mind. Still, till the great revelation I enjoyed every second of it. After that, not so much.
Just brilliant
A bit short but fun to play
A simple Point and click game made for tablets and phones. nice drawings, kinda fun story, dumb puzzles and lots of good voice actor underused.

An absolutely fantastic point-and-click adventure that features a famous lineup of voice actors and a well-written story, this game is definitely worth your money if you're a fan of the genre. It stays simple, and avoids the common trap that point-and-clicks fall into of having the solutions to puzzles be really bizarre combinations of your inventory items that no sane person would've thought of.  For the writing alone I would recommend this game, but everything else about it is brilliant too.

I am not very fond of quests. Most of the time I find them not intuitive enough. This time I felt that too. Sometimes this game is not intuitive enough. But damn how cute it is. Visually pleasant (as always I wish they made a cartoon like this), very likeable story with several funny twists. Tim did it again. Nice characters, good visuals, funny dialogues, simple and charming.

While the story is not a work of wonder, the bits of writing here and there are really nice. Puzzles in the first half of the game weren't as challenging, at least not for me. Art felt rushed in many places. Things felt visually out of place. However some scenes are great. I really like the animation and sound work.  All in all, if you like adventure games, you should play it because it's definitely not trash but also know that it's not as great as many others.  I feel (but don't really know) like this game was a time & money management fail. Hopefully will be better with Double Fine's next adventure because I like them people.

Another classic game from Double Fine! With simple 'point-and-click' interface, humourous puzzles and a thought-provoking storyline Broken Age is a great adventure for the whole family. With an amazing cast of voice actors and great graphics this game will quickly be added to your classic game list that you'll return to again, year after year.  Some of the puzzles can be tricky, but you can definately go through the game without an insane amount of frustration and/or hitting all the walk-throughs.  Voice actors include: Elijah Wood, Jack Black, Wil Wheaton, Jennifer Hale, David Kaufman, Richard Steven Horvitz, Grey DeLisle and Hynden Walch.

I loved it. From start to finish. Most comments are on act 2 being bad, and yeah there are a few cheeky moments, but further than that, a lot of fun. I may be biased because I love double fine even though this is the first adventure point and click game I ever completed, but I would definately recommend this game with all my heart.  Nice aesthetics and a story that you want to have explained and unravelled.

This is wonderful, clever & silly game. There are interesting puzzles - enough to get you thinking but nothing too complex & no hunt the pixels. Great to have a female poc lead & the stories interact beautifully. Art work & sound is lovely & immersive.

I purchased Broken Age to introduce my girlfriend to the point and click genre and it has been perfect so far. It's funny and just challenging enough for someone new to these types of games. I've been letting her take the lead for the most part and it's actually been really enjoyable to just sit back and watch. Hardcore puzzle fans might be disappointed because there are a lot of hints and many times just interacting with anything you can in the environment will lead you to a solution. That said, the music and presentation have a cinematic quality that really make this game work as an interactive story. Looking forward to more!
I played this game and was like 'Oh man, wow.' And then I was done playing this game and then I was sad.

A breathtaking story with equally amazing artwork. The voice work is top notch, and the art direction blew me away. The ending leaves you on the edge of your seat, begging for the next part that will come out later this year. A must buy.
I love clouds
This game is what I have been waiting for ever since Day of the Tentacle.  It's funny and clever which is the kind of game you just can't find any more. Buy this game you will love it.

All your hopes and dreams!!  Two years, well worth the wait. Broken Age kicks off this year to a spectacular start! A full roster of charming characters in a wonderland setting that evokes and dazzles your sense of childhood wonder. Are you ready to be thoroughly amazed? Two protagonists with destinies entwined, braving themselves for the truth unknown. Are you ready for the adventure of two lifetimes? Get ready, because THIS is truly a game to behold.

This game really shows that Tim Schafer definitely still has his touch he had during the golden age of LucasArts. Recent years have seen the rebirth of the Adventure Game genre, and games such as Broken Age are a delightful addition to the market.

Broekn Age is a triumph.  Such a bold, energetic leap into a new age of Adventure Gaming.  Beautiful Artwork & amination, fantastic soundtrack, superb voice acting, and intuitive design all support a top rate narrative from Tim Schafer and Double Fine.  Such inovation. Much point. So click. Wow.
If you have ever loved classic point and click adventures, you need to play this game. If you haven't tried them, you should start here.

Let me be clear here. I am someone who has never played an adventure game before. This game is awesome. The art is awesome. The characters don't annoy me and are suprisingly awesome. The writing is awesome. The puzzles are awesome. Double fine, you beautiful, beautiful studio, you have given me another game I love that is awesome.

An amazing game that I feel might just inspire other artists to create more Point and Click adventure games. You get to experience truely fun and quirky characters, paired with wonderful art work and design that add to the world of the story. The puzzles always feel on-task and never out of the way, yet still serve to challenge you. Awesome game! I'm excited for Act 2!

Broken Age is everything I was hoping it would be - a 'modern' adventure game with an amazing story and excellent art. It is exactly the game that would be created if the genre hadn't gone dormant for 20 years

If you like the old school adventure games, then for that reason alone, this game is worth trying. Schafer's trying to bring back the genre, and Broken Age is his first step in that direction.   On the whole, Broken Age is a great game -- excellent story and writing, voice work is top notch, visuals are wonderful, and the music is pleasant to listen to as you traverse across location and story.  My only complaint is that the game's first act itself is very short (I spent no more than 3 hours on it), which is mostly because the puzzles are very simple. Moving along in the game does not require many mental acrobatics, ultimately. The solutions to most obstacles aren't that far out of reach, and so you'll likely find yourself breezing right through the game.  Regardless, I'm really looking forward to act 2.
Best adventure game I've played in years. Doublefine did a fantastic job! The humor is beyond what I hoped for.
10/10, Would go back in time and kickstart it again!

Broken Age Act 1 is released.  Like many on here I am a backer of this project and have much love and respect for Double Fine. You many have read so far that a lot of people claim they are not getting much bang for buck here, let's iron out a few things shall we? I will sum it up this way : Beautiful art, compelling and rich story, voice work is simply perfect. Puzzles are mid ground, seems like they are warming you in, some easy and it mainly feels they do not want to frustrate the player and just keep things at a steady pace and the enjoyment flowing. (something that has plagued video games for years) Finding a middle ground for people's skills is a hard one, you can appreciate if you are looking to mass market your game then they did this just right. Bottom line - they set out to make a modern take on the adventure genre, they've done that and it works. People got what they paid for with a secound act to come, most adventure games take less time to complete.  Do people feel they deserved more? Apparently so, but games are expensive to make and as the kickstarter money pile grew in number, so in turn did the scope of the game in question. I think it was always made clear this is what we were going to get and I for one am happy. The writing is just fantastic and I would recommend this in a heartbeat, so here I am doing just that.
It's another peek into the strange mindscape of Tim Schafer.
So excellent. The characters and writing are top notch. If you want a game that actually has personality, click buy now!

It truely delivers on its promise of pointing and clicking. It is a carefully modern take on the classic point&click game I remember as a young'n. So far its curiously entertaining. Still trying to work out to do with all these items!

After a long wait as a Kickstarter backer I can say I am satisfied with the outcome. The jokes hit home and the ending of act one is surprisingly satisfying considering act two is coming later in 2014.  The fun factor is higher for this game compared to classic adventure games because the ratio of plot and exploration to frustratingly difficult puzzles is much better. I didn't get blocked on any of the puzzles for more than a few minutes and all the conversations were interesting/funny.
Well worth the wait :) Hearkens back to the days of old adventure games, Thank you Double Fine :D The wait for act 2 begins.....
Broken Age reminds me of the point-and-click adventure golden-era.

Point and Clicking is back! And there's a reason 'pointing' and 'clicking' is the top key features, that's what you do. The two main characters Shay and Vella are tired of living a normal life and wants to shake things up abit. And oh my do they.  Buy it! Seriously.  PS: Took me alittle under 3 hours to complete.
Short but sweet. More of an interactive story but the story is very very good. Lots of humor. I laughed out loud several times.
Beautiful game. Rather short, but it's only act1 of the full game. Waiting for the rest.
Highly recommended for fans of classic adventure games! Great writing, artwork, and voice acting.
An excellent Adventure game with very good pacing and an engrossing story.
Totally amazing!!! Double Fine is one of the greatest. I just hope Act 2 is a lot longer...is that too much to hope for?
Excellent return to adventures from Tim Schafer, with an intriguing art style and world. Way too short of course, but episode 2 is on the way.

I'm a big fan of adventure games and Broken Age did not dissapoint. The graphics were awesome and the story was phenomenal. The only downside is that it is a bit on the short side. I am used to longer adventure games and this one ended a bit too soon. Looking forward to Part 2.
Subtle, sophisticated and adorable. Required playing for anyone who has fond memories of the golden era of point-and-click adventures.

Seriously awesome old school adventure game.   This game is relaxing to play like I'm eight years old again and the only things to worry about are eating mac and cheese and playing a video game.  Where are you episode two?

What a beautiful game... all art painted exquisitly, even if you don't like click-adventure games, buy it and use it as your backdrop, like a painting. The story is endearing and the characters superbly well written. This could be a blockbuster movie, it touches elements of the latest Wachowski without being confusing. The puzzles are cute but a bit outdated, it doesn't matter, this is a piece of interactive art, a tamagotchi with a story.
Really enjoyed the game and waiting for the act 2. 5/5

Fund and a nice art style. Excellent voice acting. Only real negative is that the locations have a few too many 'flavor' hotspots - places that arent needed to solve puzzles, but which result in your character making some comment when clicked - and that damages the immersion.

A return to form for Tim Schafer, Broken Age (Act 1) is a wonderful little adventure. Some of the puzzles are a bit straightforward, which may help bring new players to the genre, the art is whimsical without being overly cutesy, the music fits each location, and the characters are well developed and voiced. Engaging and enjoyable. 5/5

Double Fine does it again with a visually amazing adventure game that will leave you mind-boggled. The voice acting was impeccable, and the story refreshing and charming. I'm greatly looking forward to the next chapter!
Broken game for the broken people of broken age. Try it.

Broken Age is beautifully designed, in a way that brings back childhood memories of point and click games, and the story is wonderful and interesting. Be ready though, because this first part will put forth a lot of questions and you will be anxciously awaiting the second part.
A point and click adventure with a story only Double Fine could come up with.
I've never played a better point-and-click adventure. I can't wait for Act II!

Just completed Act 1 and what can I say... I am completely sucked into the story! I can't wait to see what happens! If you are an adventure game enthusiast or if you simply love a great adventure, buy this game. Tim Schafer has no equal in the Adventure genre. MY TIP- play through Shay's story first! You can switch through them if you want, but it feels very cohesive to play Shay --> Vella... you'll see why. This game is well worth the money and I can't wait for Act 2!
Finally got around to playing Broken Age Act 1, cute and a definite change to the games that I've been playing recently. Looking forward to Act 2.
Really great game so far. The art is fantastic, making it feel more like a story book than a game.

This game is brilliant! It has the charm of the classic King's Quest as well as its beautiful and vibrant world. I have just beat it and I must say the story arc is superbly developed, and without throwing spoilers, I cant wait for more!

To tell you anything about the story of this game would pretty much be the worst sin anyone can create so let me tell you the rest of it. The voice acting? Spot on beauty. The art style? Gorgeous. The story? Honestly its great so I shouldnt tell you a SINGLE SECOND. The Humor? It's ♥♥♥♥ing Double Fine, creators of Psychonauts. So yes its hilarious. Trust me when I say this game is worth buying full price, or if you need to, when its on sale.   Get it, you won't regret it.

Elijah Wood (Frodo) is the main voice actor. It has a powerful, moving, and funny story. It's made by the same people as Psychonauts. Need I say more? Maybe you won't like this if you really hate point and click adventures but if not this is probably my favorite of the genre in terms of artwork, style, story, and polish.
Amazing art style and a simple but charming story make this a great adventure game created by the Godfather of the genre

I REALLY like this game i love the graphics, the story, and the puzzles. If you dont have it i think its up to you to get Broken Age. BUT i think you should get it if you if youre looking for video games to buy on steam.

I love the hand drawn graphics, it gives the game a really cool feel to it. The ending is really interesting and the entire concept for the game is fun. Can't wait for act 2 to come out, the ending of act 1 really got me excited for it. Short amount of gameplay for the price, but still worth it. (Especially considering the release of act 2 will probably double the amount of gameplay for the cost)
Great story, characters and music. I really loved playing it and am looking forward to the next act. The quests are easy but make sense so they aren't annoying.
Good story with logical puzzles that require just a bit of thinking. Loved every second of the first act and I can't wait for Act II.
A really fun point and click game with a -really- interesting story and lovable characters. I found myself giggling a lot throughout and was left wanting when the game ended. Short, but very sweet.
Prepare to get sucked up in an amazing story.

This game a typical point and click quest games like the awesome lucasarts/sierra quest games in the 80-90s. I have to admit, that backing this game on kickstarter - i had doubts and was really worried they would choose to follow the route of Walking Dead game (not that it;s bad, just very simplified), but i was wrong and it turned out to be an excellent game. Witty and charming humour, beautiful art, voiceover and general story setting - this game has all that.   And although the first act (that's currently available) is really short - i encourage you to buy this game - It's amazing how many fond memories of the old quest games before this game brings and for that alone it's worth its money.

Its been too long since the last double fine gmae and boy did they make up for it! following tradition, the game has an AMAZING STORY and an 'insteresting' cast of characters. plus amazing voice acting by actors like will wheaton. the music is beutiful, the scenery is just as great! you wont want to put it down once you start! and remember: 'beware the trees!'
The story and dialogue are well written and the hand-painted characters and environments are absolutely stunning to behold. I can't wait for the second act!

Just finished act 1. personal thoughts on this game was it is amazing! great start to a story. I enjoyed every bit of it so far from the voice acting to the art style that has this fresh and original look to it and the story is just amazing. I can't wait for act 2 to show up. On side notes without letting any spoilers I do recomend this game and the ending is very interesting.

Great fun, great voice acting, exactly as quick and well-written as you'd expect from Tim Schaefer and crew. A wonderful, whimsical reimagining of the point-and-click adventure game. I wish it were 10 times as long.
This game has so much heart and is outstandng, if you like adventure games or don't go for it.
Just couldn't put this game down for long. Can't wait for Act 2.

Short, but absolutely enjoyable from the word go. The art style is like a storybook illustrated with pastels, and the animation style matches it perfectly. The puzzles in Act 1 aren't complete stumpers like you might find in some of the classic LucasArts adventure games, but there are plenty of 'aha' moments that'll make you feel clever. I'm sad that Act 2 isn't in the package yet, but I think it's worth the price of admission at 25.00 (the price as of launch on 1/28/14). If you've ever enjoyed a traditional point and click adventure game, you're almost guaranteed to like this. Act 1 ends on a cliffhanger (albeit a satisfying one) and Act 2 won't be out until later in 2014, so caveat emptor in that regard. This was the first thing I ever kickstarted, and I have to say I'm pretty thrilled by how it turned out.

Loved it. Cant wait for Act 2. Beatiful game with interesting characters. It has more personality in inventory items than most AAA games do in a full 5 hour game of killing facless mercs or terrorists.
An exciting return of the point and click adventure! Can not wait for part 2!

To be honest, I was getting worried as I saw the reports of the game being pushed back and everything. I didn't back it to begin with, but I was worried for all of those other backers.  Thankfully, I can say that I don't think they wasted their money. I don't think I wasted my money by paying $25 for it either.  It's a really solid, good game. I'm excited for Act 2.

Beautiful, funny, moving. Still suffers from some of the old Adventure Game hiccups (pixel hunt has been replaced with large cursor hunt, puzzles still require one sometimes obtuse solution like multiple sharp objects but each one can only cut specific things), but in the end it felt fresh and nostalgic at the same time. A real masterpiece of an adventure game.

Fantastic story, beautiful visuals, and quick witted. If you grew up with Tim Schaffer adventure games and you've been waiting for more, jump on this. If you're too young to remember those games, give it a try.   It's on the short side, but that problem should be remedied when the free update comes out later this year.

An excellent point-and-click adventure that serves exceptionally well at introducing people to the genre or even gaming in general. Act 1 contains easy puzzles that will ease newcomers into adventure game tropes while still entertaining veteran gamers.  The presentation is also delivered in a manner worthy of the Double Fine name. Very high quality that you would expect from a AAA title: engaging plot, meticulously detailed art and animation, and a script and voice cast that will make you wish the game never ends.  Act 1 is ultimately a satisfying appetizer that is enjoyable yet leave space for more that will only be satiated by the main course that is Act 2. Purchasing Broken Age will ensure you will get your kicks today while longing for what's to come tomorrow.

This is a great game. Act one was short but the story really made up for it. Also I loved the voice acting and the puzzle solving. I felt that this game was hard enough for an adult but easy enough for a kid.

Great story, awesome characters and just the right level of complexity for a leisure game. Feels very polished and you feel it's a work of art created by passionate gamers/developers.   Also, huge gigantic nostalgia value for players of classic adventure games. Buy it now! :)
Double Fine did it. Yes, there’s still one more act to go before this whole thing is technically “complete,” but the $3.3 million crowdfunding success paid for one helluva half-game.

bottom line is I could not pull myself away from this game until I played all the way through, and I plan on going through again just to play with the different dialog tree options.  The climax of the first episode literally gave me chills, I really cannot wait until the second part is released!

The first half-hour or so of playing this game I just couldn't believe how beautiful it is. I had seen the trailers of course but they just don't do playing this game on a nice big screen any justice. It really goes to show what we lost the moment somewhere in the early 2000s when we had convinced ourselves that 2D graphics were outdated and had to be confined to flash games, low-bugdet indie productions and side-scrollers. I really think the visuals of this game are ground-breaking. Breaking new ground also means that the graphics aren't perfect. You will occasionally still see pixels at certain zoom levels, a problem that just does not exist in this form for 3D games or games that don't zoom.  Music and voice acting are also great. Elijah Wood is not just a big name to sell more copies, he's just genuinely great for the role and incredibly nuanced. It's fun just listening to his voice.  There are a lot of interesting characters and I found the storylines compelling and quite surprising.  The thing that's criticized the most is the linearity and puzzle difficulty. Well, is this game as complex as Day of the Tentacle or does its world feel as grand as that of Monkey Island? No, surely not. If that's what you're looking for then you should at least wait for Act 2 to come out. Act 1 is meant to be a warm-up for Act 2 but we'll of course have to wait and see how this turns out. I can't say any of these criticisms occured to me personally while playing. I had hoped for more character interaction but the two plots are very much separated throughout Act 1. I quickly forgot that while playing though but I do still hope that we will see more DotT style interaction between the main characters in Act 2.  So in summary, if you're after some serious brain teasing, you'll have to find it somewhere else. If you can enjoy a good story, beautifully told in every way and garnished with some puzzles along the way to keep you invested, then this is definitely a game for you.

Fantastic game and I'm not just saying that because I backed it ;-) It's funny, interesting and original. The art style is fantastic. There is an excellent balance between puzzle difficulty and subtle hints from the game.
Glad I backed this game! One of the greatest and unique experiences in contemporary videogames!

Do yourself a favor, buy this and support this great team. Such an amazing game. Fresh, exciting and most importantly full of heart and passion. Congrats to Tim & the whole team over at Double Fine. You truly have something great here. :)

Good adventrue games are hard to come across these days. This one goes far above the rest and is definitely on of my favorites. Eventhough I've only played a little over an hour, I can already tell I will LOVE this game.
A masterpiece, everything about this game is brilliant – story, art, music, etc. And what a joy it is to finish a great game and find your name in the credits.

Broken Age is certainly one of the best point-and-click games I have played. The storylines are a delight, and with Act 2 coming as a free update later this year, I do not think the price is too much to ask. The storylines are really well-written and original. The art is absolutely beautiful. Broken Age is entertaining and visually stunning. I recommend it.

Just finished Act1. I didn't back this game during kickstarter - it has enough of backers back then. But from that very moment I was looking for Double Fine Adventure -> Broken Age. Now when I have bought and finished first act I have to say that this game was very, very easy. But it doens't matter! The plot is so great, interesting, graphics - wondrous, with good music played by actual musicians, and not by synthesator or other digital tool to create sounds. Tim - I'm really waiting for the act II!
Aaaah, such a beautiful game! I just wish it was a little longer... I can't wait for the next installment! :D
Nostalgically inspiring, very surpising and atmospherically engrossing, can't reccomend enough.
really good story, how they come together at the end!

I'm a little sad at the length of Act I, beating it in a couple sessions and ending at a little over 4 hours, but the game was enjoyable the whole way through. Each character was memorable, the puzzles weren't too frustrating (although I did have to look one up just like the features say), and there was a plot twist I /thought/ I had figured out only to be totally wrong and blown away by the truth.  This definitely has that Tim Schafer charm, and I'm glad I chose to back it. Can't wait for Act II!
Short but Sweeeet

This is pretty much the greatest adventure game since the old Lucasarts days. No seriously, if you have any good memories, any whatsoever, of playing Monkey Island, Day of the Tentacle, Indiana Jones and the fate of Atlantis, Full Throttle or the Dig. You owe it to yourself to get this right now. Turn off your phone for the next 4 hours, pour yourself a drink (since you weren't old enough to drink when you played the aforementioned games.) Sit down and play this absolute gem.
What a wonderful, wonderful game. It fits together tightly, with excellent places and peoples and dialog. Yes, only half the game is done - but what a half!
Broken age is an excellent and witty adventure game. Snag it if you haven't.
I always enjoy a good adventure game. This one looks to satisfy.
All the charm of a Double Fine game wrapped up in a classic adventure game package. While you wait for this to officially come out pick up Psychonauts and Costume Quest as well :D
This is an awesome return to the glory days days of adventuring, and not for many years have I been so completely engrossed in a game. Miss out on this one at your own peril.
I wholeheartly recommend this game for a large variety of reasons I shall withhold until you've played it yourself. Buy it. Right now. Then play it.
If an adventure game has ever made you smile, even once, give this one a shot.

Amazing point and click adventure game, i got stuck just the right amount to feel this is not way too easy but i didn't get to the classic point of trying to use the rubber chicken with the pulley in the middle on every pixel on screen. I am biased, i am a backer for this game, i love the past works of Lucasarts games and this one is a real treat for any fan of the genre, it is modernized in all the correct places and still has that unique Tim Schafer charm. 5/5 from me :)
Wonderful game. If you like adventures then you don't want to miss this one! Buy it now!

Great story and fantastic art direction. It feels like a true adventure game for the current era of gaming. Even though it's broken in seperate acts, the first act has enough content to be satisifying. Can't wait for the next acts.   If you can be a backer for the game, I would highly recommend it just for access to the documentary series. The documentary has been an interesting insight into the game's development and doesn't contain spoilers.

Schafer is back and as strong as ever. Although not ideal that the game is releasing in 2 parts the first part has proven strong enough to make me want the second! The visuals are amazing with the whole game feeling like a living painting thanks to the style of Nathan 'Bagel' Stapley, and the voice cast is amazing with some of the best voices I've heard on characters in a long while, especially David Kaufman's vocal work for Marek!  It's a shame the game has lost the old school days of Point and Click games where you'd have multiple verb options to try and solve puzzles, opting more for a touch device optimized 'rub this on that' interface but I can't blame them as we live in an age where quicker, easier to solve puzzles to quickly do while on the bus are in demand now.  Even with this easier than classic gameplay I'd strongly recommend this game to old and new gamers alike.  Also if you enjoy this I'd recommend checking out previous work by the Double Fine team and Tim Schafer!
Everybody needs this!

Beutiful art style, enchanting music, great story, and memorable characters. The puzzles in Act I are a bit on the easy side for adventure game veterans, but this makes it a great entry level game for those who are curious, and the second act of the game is planned to ramp up the challenge level. As of this writing, only Act I of this game is out. I'm really looking forward to Act II. Great job, DoubleFIne!
Oh.My.God Just finished act 1.  Just buy it. Its awesome.

--WARNING! EVER-SO-MILD-OUT-OF-CONTEXT-SPOILERS-- This game has a talking robotic knife that wants to kill everything and is looked down upon by his spoon compatriot. It has ice cream avalanches. It has a nav system that knits hyperspace coordinates. It has a man hanging by his underwear who is also not sympathetic. It has a girl who is much too excited about cupcakes. It has a vomiting tree. It has entire worlds that were the one-off suggestions of its backers, and small bit characters like a Post-Traumatic-Stress-addled hipster lumberjack that we kept from being thrown onto the cutting room floor.  So as a backer, I would like to present OUR game, to you, the public! Its pretty awesome for something that we all made together against some pretty heavy odds and wild expectations. Yeah, I already have it... but its silly to say I already bought it. I already MADE it, with the awesome help of our friends at Double Fine. All 90,000 of us made it, so that you can enjoy it! So go ahead, try it out!
Amazing art, characters, acting and story! Highly recomend

A beautiful and very charming interactive story, with wonderful design and quirky characters, told by the master storyteller Tim Schafer and his wonderful team at Doublefine Studios!  Well yes, what so many reviews have said so far is true....  it's a rather easy game, and puzzle-wise certainly not on par with Schafer's earlier point and click adventures, which might be the fault of the budgetary constraints, or just a concious gamedesign desicion ...in the end - who cares?   Of a good adventure game it's not the frustrating puzzles I'll remember with awe, but first and foremost the story, the overall atmosphere and the characters I meet on the way! These are the game's strenght! also the great music by Peter McConnell and the wonderful voiceacting by Elijah Wood, Jennifer Hale, Masasa Moyo and Jack Black.   Now, more than 24 hrs after my first playthrough, I still carry the memories of playing the game in my head and most importantly: my HEART. And that to me, is a very good sign and the definite proof, that Doublefine not only promised, but also delivered a great game!  Thank you Doublefine, Broken Age was the wonderful first Act of a great story - can't wait for part 2!  p.s. - I urge you to buy the version, which includes the fantastic Soundtrack be Peter McConnell! - can't stop to listen to it!

What a rare pleasure to experience something that juggles aesthetics, humor, and heart with interesting puzzles and mind blowing story. It was worth the wait for the first act, and I'm dying for the second.

An amazing experience that rekindles my love of adventure games, and all games really.  The story, art, music and sound design are stellar and all developers should take note that such an achievement can be done without AAA levels of investment.  Puzzles are part of the story and not an afterthought, and are challenging enough to keep you from hints or walkthroughs.  I can go on and on so trust me and just buy It!

Just finished the game. One of, if not THE best point and click adventure game I've ever played.  The original draw for me was that one of the protagonist's is a woman of color, and I was not dissapointed. Vela is a great character that I easily grew to love with her bravery, and Shane was hilarious and likable as well.  The art is gorgeous, the voice acting is great, and the story/world is unique. The puzzles are not too easy, and provide a unique challenge.  Overall a game that is more than worth the money I paid for it.  Looking forward to Act 2!

Nice P&C adventure, but act 1 is realy short and the riddles are somewhat easy. P&C Veterans might breeze through it. Remember that act 2 is coming out later this year though and it is included in the price. If you expect bizarre humour like DotT or Sam n Max, you might be dissapointed, but overall the game has funny dialogue that will leave you smirking and a dreamy world. The voiceacting is top notch. I would say it is a safe buy, but if you want a full, engaging p&c adventure atm, I would suggest buying 'Whispered World' instead until Broken Age has more content.
Really liked it. Can't wait for Act 2!
Ahh too awesome. I love the old style Lucas Arts adventure games and this hits the spot

I love Tim's work, huge fan, especially Grim Fandango. The art/programming/animation in this game is awesome and looks great on a HDPI display, it's really refreshing to play another game like this (Machinarium was the last). That said so far I've found the puzzles hardly puzzling at all, the hints are obvious and the puzzles are more like mini fetch quests (so far). Personally I don't find it as charming as Grim Fandango, but I prefer Burton-esque stuff personally, so maybe I'm not the best one to judge but I'm finding this game to lean towards being more childish. I don't mean any disrespect at all, it's really cool so far and I have great respect for everyone working on it, just wanted to give some constructive feedback.

Solid and clever writing with some pretty dark themes. The dialogue is witty and the voice acting is excellent.  The colorful crayon-like visuals might not be to everyone's taste but I thought it worked amazingly well.  Puzzles are kinda easy but for me that's a plus since I hate getting stuck in these kinda games.  Biggest issue is that it's way too short and ends when it starts getting really good. Bring on part 2!

Recommended for those nostalgic for old LucasArts adventure games. The art is fantastic and has a childish quality that is perfect to play with your kids and or niece and nephews.   A perfect gateway to introduce the new generation to point-and-click adventure games.
A resounding yes.
It may be a little too easy yet (part 1) - but the nice artwork, voices and storytelling make it worth playing!

I'm extraordinarily happy I backed this game. Everything screams that it is a Tim Schafer adventure game. The characters are wonderful with some funny lines. I just beat act 1 and I can't wait for the conclusion. So far the story is great, the puzzles aren't insanly hard but still make you think about things. If you love point and click adventures this has been the best one in a long time.
Short, easy, fun and funny
As good as you could have hoped and better. Only downside, it was over suprisingly quickly. Hope Act 2 will be a tad longer.
A little short with just Act 1, but fantastic art and fantastic characters.

Broken Age's story is amazing, with cerebral commentary on the nature of life goals, progress, satisfaction, intelligence, and culture. As an adventure game, it's fairly straightforward: there were only a few instances where I got stuck, and unlike some cryptic adventure games, the items and their uses are pretty logical. Finishing both stories to discover their 'link' has me impatiently waiting for their resolution in Act II.
Beautiful, touching, engaging, atmospheric, funny and charming. This game is a must-buy for adventure game fans or for fans of gaming in general.

Prettiest artystyle since Legend of Mana, wonderful voice acting delivered by Elijah Wood, Jack Black and Wil Wheaton among others. And it's all used to tell a wonderful, if so far short, story. Highly recommended.

A vary Pritty game, the story is well done. The ending made me rethink everything that had happened ealrer. my only complant is that it feels to short looking forward to act2 fixing that. The sound track is great but not sure if its something i would listen to on its own

Broken Age is everything I wanted in a point and click adventure/puzzle game when I spent hours trolling flash game websites in my formative years. The artwork is, of course, breath-taking, the voice-acting too, and the gameplay is charming and satisfying to play. One criticism I have is the length of the game, especially considering the price (although I personally got it during a flash sale) which I think checked in at around 4-5 hours for me. However, as stated in the game's description, Act 2 is being released later this year free of charge, and I will also definitely be replaying this act.   All in all, I'd recommend Broken Age if you're someone who enjoys puzzles and can appreciate the artistry and love with which this game was made.

An interesting game with an interesting story line that ends with a twist. It does not take long to beat, presumabley because it is only Act 1. I recommend the game based on what I have seen so far. It is fun, it is quick, its a nice break from the usual high stress, hack and slash type games out there.

Wow. The epitome of how a point-and-click adventure based game should be. That is the only way I can describe my experience in the wonderful world of Broken Age. In view of the game's beautiful art style, amazing soundtrack, subtle puzzles and a tale that will surprise you to no end, this is definitely a worthy purchase. Though the game itself is quite short in length (took me 4 hours to complete, but you can go even faster if you're good at solving puzzles), another act is currently in development that will completely justify this game's price point. Do yourself a favor and purchase this game if you enjoy casual point-and-clicks!
Very nice point and click puzzle game with confusing story ending which is to be continued...7/10
I love the art and the style of this game! The storyline was amazing! I cant wait for act II to come out

Act 1 of Broken Age was surprisingly challenging for me. The subtle hints meant getting innovative with whatever was lying around. I found the voice acting to be well produced however I did make ample use of the skip function as I fumbled my way through the puzzles. The artwork was reminiscent of a child's art book and accompanied by the soundtrack, the game had a dream like ambiance.   Now that I've figured out the puzzles, replaying will be easy but playing it again would be more for the sometimes witty script and the general pleasant feel of the game.
Another great Double Fine game! The ending of Act I makes me eager to play Act II when released. The artwork was great and the point and click playstyle was well implemented. (9/10)

I Kickstarted this game based on a friend's insistence, and I'm so glad I did. Great puzzles to play and kept me engaged with the unique storyline. Each part had moments of sincerity and humor. I'm impatiently waiting for the second part, so if Double Fine would please hurry up and finish it, I'd really appreciate it.
If it ain't Broke(n), don't fix it.

Tim Schafer. A god among men. A king among serfs. A tuna among red snappers.  This man has hit another home-run with a back-to-basics point and click adventure game. His overwhelming success on Kickstarter lead to an increased imagining of what this game could become. From the original ideas, the game expanded to the point where it is being released in two stages. This is the first part of the game, and what a thrill ride it is. Unexpected twists will leave you kicking and screaming while waiting for the second part.  If you were one of the lucky contributors, then you witnessed the 'making of' videos posted every two or three weeks. The number of updates and insight into the production was a surprising bonus. I'm sure they will be available to everyone in due time, as most digital items are, so do not miss this when you have a chance to watch it.  While the puzzles were fairly basic, I was enthralled with the characters and typical Schafer humor.  Brilliant.
I enjoyed this game. It was a fun, nicely drawn interesting first half to an old school adventure game. I look forward to part two to see what excitment and resolution to the story.
Sweet hand-painted visuals and witty humor. Act I done, waiting for II.

Pros: Really nice story, great music, lots of fun. Great voices, pleasant graphics. A decent, old style adventure game.  Cons: Quite simple - hardly any puzzles - and certainly nothing challenging. Way too short - 4 hours top to finish whole game, exhausting all dialouge options etc. Given lot of money raised with Kickstarter I would expect it to be twice as long (and it probably is going to be as this is only Act 1 and apparently Act 2 is going to be a free update - so we just have to be patient).

Act 1  A truly charming, well executed, point and click adventure game.  Masterfully presented and crafted with attention to detail and obvious care.  I can't wait for the second act, the cliffhanger made me thirsty for more.

Broken Age is a beautifully drawn adventure game. The game's music is awesome and the gameplay could not be easier. Unfortunately, the riddles are very easy, too. And the dialogues could also a bit more variant. But the story is good, so I would give grade B+ to this game.

Short (Really short) but sweet and fun Both main characters are easy to relate to, the plot is engaging, and the puzzles are Good but can be a little annoying I feel that the Characters and the plots carries the game, I did not regret buying this game

Beautiful, polished, fun, stimulating.   In a word. Too short.   As fun as this game is, and as worthwhile a play, I would not recomend more than 10 USD for the playing. My steam time seems a bit off as I don't think I finished this game in only 6 hours, but it was over in a day, so maybe.   It's everything you want in a partner, or adventure game, unfortunately it felt like it was over before it really began.  If you can find this on sale for 5$ definitely buy it, the devs were a bit too ambitious on this one, or perhaps they bit off more than they could chew, and coudln't manage their time and resources properly. Either way, what came out was good, just ... not good enough.  Try it! 5$ recomended price.
Story is amazing, must get. Can't wait for act 2

This is a very artfully crafted game. The visual art comes to life as though you've been dropped inside a children's story book, except the story has a much darker undertone than the art let's on. So far, I have enjoyed the first episode. Granted, I had a harder time understanding where to get the items I needed to progress on the girl's side of the story. The boy's side was easier for me, but that might be because I played his side after I finished with hers.  Both stories, however, are equally interesting plot-wise. They are both struggling with their surroundings, trying to step out of the 'fate' that has been woven for them. The end of the episode was an interesting twist that left me wanting for more. I can't wait to see what happens to our protagonists, and what the consequences of their actions will turn out to be.

This is a nice point and click adventure. A little cutesy but still good. I can play it while my kids watch and they are entertained and I don't worry about them getting nightmares. It is good enough that I plan to beat this game whenever I find the time.

The graphic, color, and gameplay are so good. Not a boring point-and-click game. I can't stop playing the game for hours to finish one part. I am waiting for act II right now, really want to see what happens next.
Great game with amazing art. The story provides subtle hints of what's left to come. Voice acting and music are superb! If you love games with a great story, play this.
amazing game that left my jaw dropped at the end
good but short

I'm not really a gamer. I don't find enjoyment in killing wolves repeadedly or getting into sword fights or flying around in internet spaceships. Broken Age on the other hand was fun, imaginative and pretty sweet.
It suffers from a bit of classic Tim Schafer adventure game ridiculousness. But it manages to be both charming, funny, and insightful. 8.5/10

10/10  I love Double Fine games, however this has to be my new favorite. The art in the game is absolutely beautiful; every scene can be framed and put up in a gallery. It really fits well to immerse you in the game. The story is great and written incredibly well. I found myself listening to every bit of dialogue each character had to offer. I really liked how your able to switch between stories whenever you felt; this was a relief because I was looking forward to both characters but wasn't sure which to play first, and with the option to switch I didn't have to choose. I would recommend this game to everyone.
This game shows more charm and more depth than most AAA games today

This game is really charming. I've only found out about this game recently, and I really liked it. I like the art style of the game, with expressive shapes and colours that match the personality of the characters and scenery. The story -in my own opinion- is different and lighthearted, along with the point and click style of gameplay makes it a very interesting, chill, and casual game to play. As for the puzzles in the game, they are sensible, easy-ish to complete, and the dialogue in the game gives clues to completing these puzzles, therefore, they're not going to make your butt hurt.  I personally liked this game very much. If you're into relaxed games, adventure or stories, I recommend Broken Age.
Act 1 is fun, colorful, and has a good hook. Looking forward to the 2nd half later in 2014.
Interesting but as of now they are still working on the episode 2.

When I played the first chapter, I liked this game. The second chapter though... It just reminds me of everything that is wrong with adventure games! All I'm doing now is just randomly clicking here and there to maybe find the answer to puzzles. They even wrote some 'funny' dialog lines for a lot of these stupid item combinations and interactions, but failed to make actually good and sensible puzzles that one can enjoy SOLVING. And my god, don't start me on navigation! Player won't run in a lot of situations and you have to click and wait while he's slooowing moving towards where you clicked.

[Spoiler-free review]  This game showed so much promise. The first act was mostly a lot of fun, I really enjoyed the story, and I was excited to see what was going to happen next. The game felt really polished and relatively well-designed, with only some minor annoyances.  But the second act completely negated all the good from the first. It felt poorly designed, poorly executed, and like they just rushed it to market rather than properly designing the puzzles or worrying about the story.   Rather than explaining any of the things I was excited to find out, the second half just introduced major plot holes that were then either entirely ignored or quite poorly explained. And, most damning for a game, the gameplay and puzzles were increasingly frustrating, not fun, and arbitrarily difficult to figure out. Random and entirely unconnected things needed to be done in a certain order; there were things I needed to do that the character would in no way have knowledge about; and the puzzles were so poorly explained that I sometimes couldn't even figure out what the problem was that I was trying to solve (meaning that I had no hope of solving it).  The only way I could finish act 2 was by following a detailed walkthrough -- something I usually try to avoid -- and even with the walkthrough to guide me, one of the final puzzles was so poorly designed that it took me over an hour just to figure out how the puzzle even worked. Guessing correctly at the solution didn't ease my frustration since it's a puzzle that needs to be solved in different ways several times.   I would generally recommend the first half, but I would definitively NOT recommend the second half. Stay away! It was not worth the frustration. This game has so much promise -- I really wanted to like it! -- but was too poorly designed and executed to me to recommend it.

Great story, art, animation and some brilliant puzzles. Loved the characters. Loved the tree jokes.  It gets more difficult later on and I had to consult a walkthrough a couple of times, but that's sort of normal for me with point and click adventures. Sure, a small minus, but all the more satisfying when I got it right. I was annoying that I had to redo things with the final puzzle, but the concept was brilliant storywise, as a metaphor. You'll see what I mean.

Was somewhat interesting. The first act was better than the second. The second act was reusing existing environments and tons of backtracking and trial-and-error to pad the game length.  Ending note (Potential spoiler):    The ending was terrible. It seemed extremely rushed and felt like the game just came to a completely abrupt end.

This game gives modern gamers a retro-style adventure game puzzling experience (take that however you want). Brilliant aesthetics and absorbing story. Would have enjoyed it more if they finished the game!

Act one enjoyable exploring a delightfully whimsical scenario. Act two frustratingly obtuse puzzles and a standard end to the story.  Overall  Verdict — Worth playing for the art, just google a solution whenever you get stuck.
not worth the money. Story is shallow puzzles made by a mad man with an unlogical sense of thinking. Puzzles not hard but unlogical and thus frustrating
Great writing. Great characters. Great animation. Get it.
This is an amazing game!
An almost perfect game, with beautiful visuals and music. A little disappointing ending is the only thing I can sincerely complain about.

For those who love point and click games, I recommend it. I loved the story and the puzzles are nice, though Act 2 has some puzzles that are be a bit confusing and illogical. You feel like there's a lot of unexplored potential. Still, it's worth playing in my opinion. 7/10

This game is really really really really good. It's not super long but I think it's totally worth what you pay for it. The voice acting is great, the music is great, the dialogue is great, the overall gameplay is above great! Give it a try and I promise you won't regret it :)
Love this game. The art is captivating, the dialogue funny and engaging, and the story is interesting and well thought out.
Comfortable graphic, vivid facial expression and easy interaction with the whole scene, i.e. by only mouse.

+ Great art + Great humor + Nontrivial and surprising story + Puzzles that require thinking and some creativity (and observation of the world) + Not too many stupid puzzles that require behaving exactly as authors imagined - In second part some puzzles are really puzzling (:D), but not stupid

Just played Broken Age for the second time. My first run through of Act 2 was so challenging in spots that I had to force myself to finish the game. Then I uninstalled it for months and moved on.   The second run through was much more enjoyable. Granted, this was mostly because I vaguely remembered a lot of the crazy 'video game logic' that went into solving the puzzles (even after months of ignoring this game in my Library), but not getting so frustrated allowed me to enjoy Act 2 for what it is.   Yes, Act 1 is still better because it introduces you to this amazing world and most of the characters. However, Act 2 isn't as bad once you're not driving yourself crazy trying to guess all of the actions and timing that go into certain puzzles. You can just sit back and enjoy the progression of the story, which makes the eventual ending seem much less abrupt.   That being said, I still needed a guide to figure out the timing of the Plague Dam events. If I ever play Broken Age again, I'm sure I'll need a guide then too.
I loved everything about this game. Art, music, characters, puzzles, it's all great.
The artwork in this game is excellent, same with the soundtrack. Although honestly, while I found the end of the game worth it, getting to the final few steps was a little repetitive.

Pros: -Looks great, sounds great -Funny and charming, as you'd expect from Double Fine -Memorable and amusing NPCs -Puzzles are mostly fun and fair, and hints are available through dialogue  Cons: -Shay is boring and flat, and you spend half the game controlling him -Act 2 is noticeably less polished than Act 1 -Story leaves quite a few noticeable hanging threads, ending is rushed and disappointing -Lots of wasted time backtracking and going through dialogue menus in Act 2 -Seriously, the ending sucks   Kickstarter hype backlash aside, this is a mostly above-average P&C adventure that bogs down a bit toward the end. I'd be bummed if I sent Tim Schafer a month's rent for it, but if you can pick it up on sale it's definitely worth a look if you're a fan of the genre and don't mind being disappointed by the ending.

Great puzzles and interesteing concept to play as two very different characters with opposing points of view. Who has the whole truth and who is doing the right thing? Ending was okayish,very children book type of ending, but it adds to the charm of the game.   Liked the characters and challenges. Also grat feature to allow some cutscenes to be skippable.

Broken Age is a wonderful narrative adventure game. The story has moments half way through where things click and you start to understand what's going on and it's a great feeling when that happens.  The art style is really refreshing and colorful, and the voice acting is great too.  The puzzle can get a little complicated, difficult and repetitive, but they certaintly don't make games like this anymore. That's the main reason why I enjoyed it so much. Awesome adventure game. Ignore the Schafer haters that seem to have nothing better to do than hate on a man that has done much more good than bad.
7/10 TJBs
Such a fun game, creative characters and a story that got me hooked . It got me back to enjoyed point and click style games that I used to play as a kid.

This game truly is a masterpiece. The appealing artwork, original story, unique characters, talented voice actors, and fun gameplay make for an experience you won't forget. I enjoyed the fact that you can switch back and forth between the main protagonists. This helped when I became frustrated with a particular puzzle. I do wish the characters had even more interaction with each other though.
